sp.p: He has heard of your Ladyſhip's partiality for his ſon, but is ſo incenſed at the irregularity of his conduct, he intends, if poſſible, to diſinherit him, and to preſent me hither, to paſs me on you for him, deſigning to treat the poor young gentleman himſelf as an impoſtor, in hopes you'll baniſh him from your heart and houſe.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I thank thee, friend, for thy caution —is Sir George ſuch a parent—what's thy name?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Richard Buſkin, Ma'am, the ſtage is my profeſſion—in the 'Squire's late excurſion we contracted an intimacy, and I ſaw ſo many good qualites in him, that I could not think of being the inſtrument of his ruin, nor deprive your Ladyſhip of ſo good a huſband as I am certain he will make you.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Then Sir George intends to diſown him.

sp.speaker: HARRY
sp.p: Yes Ma'am, I've this moment told the young gentleman of it; he's determined, for a jeſt, to return the compliment, by ſeeming to treat Sir George himſelf as an impoſtor.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, t'will be a juſt retaliation, and indeed what my uncle deſerveth, for his cruel intentions both to his ſon and me.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: (without) What has he run away again?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: That's mine uncle.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, here's my father, and my ſtanding out that I'm not his ſon, will raiſe him into the heat of a battle, ha, ha, ha, (aſide) Here he is, Madam, now mind how he'll dub me a 'Squire.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p:
Well my Lady, was'nt it as my wild rogue ſet you, all tho' calcavell as capers, you've been cutting in the garden. You ſee here I have brought him into line of battle again—you villain, why do you drop a ſtern there, throw a ſalute ſhot, buſs her bob-ſtays,
bring to, and come down ſtraight as a maſt, you dog.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Uncle, who is this?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Who is he—egad, that's an odd queſtion, to the fellow that has been cracking your walnuts.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: He's bad at his leſſon.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Certainly, when he ran from ſchool— why don't you ſpeak, you lubber, you are curſed modeſt—before I came, 'twas all down among the poſies; here, my Lady, take from a father's hand, Harry Thunder.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: That is what I may not.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: There, I thought you would diſguſt her, you flat fiſh.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: (Takes Rover's hand.) Here, take from my hand Harry Thunder.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Oh, this is your ſham Sir George,— (Apart to Harry)

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, I've been telling the Lady, and ſtill ſeem to humour him.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I ſhan't though; how do you Abrawang?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Abrawang!

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: You look like a good actor; aye, that's very well indeed. Never, never loſe ſight of your character; you know Sir George is a noiſy, turbulent, wicked old knave; bravo! Pout your under lip, purſe your brows:—Very well; but damn it, Abrawang, you ſhould have put a little red on your noſe—mind a rule, never play an old man without a red noſe.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I'm in ſuch a fury.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Well we know that.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Who is this?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Some puppy unknown.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: And you don't know this gentleman?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Excellent well! he's a fiſhmonger.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Ah, What!

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Yes; father and ſon are determin'd not to know each other.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p:
Come, Dick, give the Lady a ſpecimen of
your talent, Motleys, your only wear, ha, ha, ha, a fool I met, a fool in the foreſt. Here comes Audry.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: La! warrent, what features!

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: 'Sblood! what's this?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: A homely thing, Sir, but ſhe's my own.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Your's, you moſt audacious!—What this ſlut?

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: I thank the Gods for my ſlutiſhneſs.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: (To Rover,) You know this youth.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: My friend, Horatio; I wear him in my heart, yea, in my heart of hearts, as I do this— (kiſſes her.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Such freedom with my niece, before my face. Do you know that Lady? Do you know my ſon, Sir?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Be quiet; Jaffier has diſcovered the plot, and you can't deceive the ſenate.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, my conſcience would not let me carry it through.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Aye, his conſcience hanging about the neck of his heart, ſays good Launcelot and good Gobbo, or as aforeſaid good Launcelot Gobbo, take to thy heels and run away.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Why, my Lady, explain—ſcoundrel and puppy unknown.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Ma'am, I forgot to tell you our old neighbour Banks and his ſiſter wants you.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I come—Uncle, I've heard thy father was kind to theee; return that kindneſs to thy child— if the lamb in wanton play doth fall amongſt the waters, the ſhepherd taketh him out, inſtead of plunging him in deeper till he dieth—though thy hairs now be grey, I'm told once was flaxen; in ſhort, he's too old in folly, who cannot excuſe youth. Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I'm an old fool! well, that's damn'd civil of you, Madam Niece; and I'm a grey ſhepherd, with his lambs in the ditch; but as for you, Mr. Goat, I'll—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: My dear Abrawang, give up the game; her Ladyſhip in ſeeming to take you for her uncle, has been only humming you—What, the devil, don't you think the divine creature knows her own true-born uncle?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Certainly, to be ſure ſhe knows me.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Will you have done?—Zounds, man, my honored father was here himſelf this day—her ladyſhip knows his perſon.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Your honored father, and who the devil's your honor'd ſelf?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Now, by my father's ſon, that's myſelf it ſhall be ſun, or moon, or Cheſhire-cheeſe—I budge ſtill crop and cropp'd.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What do you bawl out to me about Cheſhire-cheeſe.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: And I ſay; as the ſaying is, your friend has told me all; but to convince you of my forgiveneſs, in our play, as you're rough and tough, I caſt your character the Wreſtler—I'll do Orlando, kick up your heels before the whole court.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I'll—why, dam'me, I'll—and you, you undutiful chick of an old pelican (Lifts up his cane.)

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: What are you at here, cudgelling people about?—But, Mr. Buckſkin, I've a word to ſay to you in private.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Buckskin, take that (ſtrikes him.)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Why dam'me, Mr. Abrawang, you're a moſt obſtinate drum, and very—

div.stage: Enter LAMP, TRAP, JANE, and SERVANT MAID.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: All the world's a ſtage, and all men and women—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: The men are rogues, and the women huſſies. (Beats them off, and ſtrikes Rover)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: A blow, Eſſex, a blow, an old raſcally impoſtor; ſtigmatize me with a blow—I muſt not put up with it.—Zounds! I ſhall be tweak'd by the noſe all round the country. If I can get the country lad to ſteal me a pair of piſtols, ſtrike me, ſo may this arm daſh him to the earth like a dead dog, deſpite, pride, ſhame, and the name of villain light on me, if I don't bring you Mr. Abrawang. Exit.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Madam, I would have paid the rent of my little cottage; but I dare ſay it was without your Ladyſhip's conſent that your Steward has turned me out, and put my neigbour in poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: My Steward oppreſs the poor! I did not know it indeed.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: The pangs of adverſity I could bear; but the innocent partner of my misfortunes, my unhappy ſiſter—

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I did deſire Ephraim to ſend for thy ſiſter; did ſhe dwell with thee, and both now without a home? let her come to mine.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: The hand of miſery hath ſtruck me beneath your notice.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p:
Thou doſt miſtake; to need my aſſiſtance is the higheſt claim to my attention—let me ſee her. (Exit Banks.) I could chide myſelf that theſe paſtimes have turned mine eyes from the houſe of woe. Ah, think ye proud and happy affluent, how many in your dancing moments pine in want, drink their ſalt tears —their morſel the bread of miſery, and ſhrinking from the cold blaſt, into their cheerleſs hovels!
Enter BANKS introducing AMELIA. Thou art welcome: I feel myſelf intereſted in thy concern.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I judge thou wert not always unhappy, tell me thy condition, then I ſhall better know how to ſerve thee: is thy brother thy ſole kindred?

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: I had a huſband and a ſon.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Widow, if it is real, not images, thou wouldeſt forget—impart to me thy ſtory, 'tis rumour'd in the village thy brother was a clergyman, tell me.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Madam, he was; but he has loſt his early patron, and he's now poor and unbeneficed.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: But thy huſband.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p:
By this brother's advice now (twenty years
ſince) I was prevailed on to liſten to the addreſſes of a young ſea officer, for my brother had been chaplain in the navy; but, to our ſurprize and mortification, we diſcovered, by the honeſty of a ſailor, in whom we put confidence, that the Captain's deſign was only to decoy me into a ſeeming marriage; our humble friend intreated of us to put the deceit on his maſter, by concealing from him that my brother was not in orders; he, flattered with the hopes of procuring me an eſtabliſhment, gave into ſuppoſed impoſition, and performed the ceremony.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Duplicity, even with a good intent, is ill.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Madam, the event has juſtified your cenſure, for my husband, not knowing himſelf really bound by any legal tie, abandoned me—I followed him to the Indies; diſtracted, till ſeeing him, I left my infant at one of our ſettlements; but after a fruitleſs ſearch, on my return, I found the friend, to whoſe care I committed my child, was compelled to retire from the ravages of war, but where I could not hear—rent with agonizing pangs, without a child or husband, I again ſaw England, and my brother, who wounded himſelf with remorſe for being the cauſe of my misfortunes, ſecluded himſelf from all joys of ſocial life, and invited me to partake the comforts of ſolitude in that aſylum, from whence we have both juſt now been driven.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: My pity can do thee no good, yet muſt I pity thee; but reſignation to what muſt be, may reſtore peace; if my means can procure thee comfort, they are at thy pleaſure—come let thy griefs ſubſide—inſtead of thy cottage, accept thou and thy brother every convenience that my manſion can afford.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Madam, I can only thank you with (weeps)

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: My thanks are here—come thou ſhalt be chearfully—I will introduce thee to my ſprightly couſin Harry, and his father, my humorous uncle— we have delights going forward that may amuſe thee.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Kind Lady.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Come, uncle, though a quaker, thou ſee'ſt I'm merry—the ſweeteſt joy of wealth and power is to cheer one another's drooping heart, and wipe from the palid cheek the tear of ſorrow!

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter three Men, dreſſed as Sailors.

sp.speaker: 1ſt SALOR.
sp.p: WELL, lads, what's to be done?

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: We've long been upon our ſhifts, and after all our tricks, twiſts, and turns, as London was too hot for us, a trip to Portſmouth was a hit.

sp.speaker: 1ſt SAIL.
sp.p: Aye, but ſince the caſh we touched upon, pretending to be able bodied ſeamen, is now come to the laſt ſhilling, and as we deſerted, means of freſh ſupply muſt be thought on to take us to London.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: Aye, now to recruit the pocket, without hazarding the neck.

sp.speaker: 1ſt SAIL.
sp.p: By an advertiſement poſted on the ſtocks yonder, there are collectors on this road, thirty guineas offered by the quaker lady, owner of the eſta •• s round here—I wiſh we could knap any ſtraggler to bring before her, a quaker will only require yea for an oath, we might pick up this thirty guineas.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: Yes, but we muſt take care, if we fall into the hands of this gentleman that's in purſuit of us—'Sdeath, is not that his man, the old boatſwain?

sp.speaker: 1ſt SAIL.
sp.p: Don't run, I think we three are a match for him.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: Let's keep up our characters of ſailors, we may get ſomething out of him; a pitiful ſtory makes ſuch an impreſſion on the ſoft heart of a true tar, that he'll open his hard hand and drop you his laſt guinea—if we can but make him believe we were preſſed, we have him, only mind me.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: To rattle my lanthorn, Sir George's temper now always blows a hurricane.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: What cheer?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Ha, boy.

sp.speaker: 1ſt SAIL.
sp.p: Bob up with your ſpeaking trumpet.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p:
D'ye ſee, brother, this is the thing—
Enter SIR GEORGE behind, unſeen.
We three hands, juſt come home after a long voyage,
were preſſed in the river, and without letting us ſee our friends brought round to Portſmouth, and then we entered freely—'cauſe why, we had no choice— then we run—we hear ſome gentleman's in chace of us, and as the ſhots are all out, we'll ſurrender.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Surrender—then you have no ſhots left, indeed—let's ſee (feeling his pocket) I hav'n't the loading of a gun about me now, and this ſame Monſieur Poverty is a bitter enemy.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: (aſide) 'Tis the deſerters I'm after.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Meet me in an hour's time in the little wood yonder, I'll raiſe the wind to blow you into a ſafe lattitude—Keep out to ſea, my maſters the rock you'll cetainly ſplit upon.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: This is the firſt time we ever ſaw you, but we'll ſteer by your chart, for I never knew one ſeaman betray another. Exit Men.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Then they have been preſſed— I can't blame them ſo much for running away.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir George would certainly hang them.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: You lie; they ſhall eat beef and drink the King's health—run and tell them ſo—ſtop, I'll tell them myſelf.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Now you are yourſelf, and a kind gentleman, as you uſed to be.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Since theſe idle rogues are inclined to return to their duty, they ſhan't want ſea ſtores; take this money—but I'll meet them myſelf, and adviſe them as I would my own children. Exit.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Which way did this Mr. Abrawang take?— Dick Buſkin, I think, has no ſuſpicion of my intention, and ſince Sim has, without making an alarm, procured theſe piſtols, ſuch a cholerick ſpark will fight. I dare ſay. If I fall, or even ſurvive this affair, I'll leave the field of love and the fair prize to the young gentleman I've perſonated, for I'm determined to ſee Lady Amaranth no more—Oh, here comes Abrawang.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Now to relieve theſe ſea gulls—they muſt be hovering about this place.—Ha, puppy unknown!

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: You're the very man I was ſeeking for— you're not ignorant, Mr. Abrawang?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Mr. What?—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: You'll not reſign your title—oh, very well, I'll indulge you—Sir George Thunder, you honored me with a blow.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Did'n't hurt you.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, Sir, but let me proceed like a gentleman; as it's my pride to reject even favors, no man ſhall offer me an injury.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: In rank we're equal.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Are we, faith?—the Engliſh of all this is, we're to fight.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Sir, you have mark'd in me an indelible ſtain, only to be waſh'd out by my blood.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Why I've only one objection to fighting you.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: What's that, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: That you're too brave a lad to be kill'd.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Brave! no, Sir; at preſent I wear the ſtigma of a coward.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Zounds, I like a bit of fighting— hav'nt had a morſel a long time—don't know when I ſmelt gunpowder, but to bring down a woodcock.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Take your ground.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I'm ready—but are we to thruſt with bull-ruſhes, like two frogs, or like two ſquirrels, pelt one another with nut-ſhells, for I don't ſee any other weapons here.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Sir, here are the weapons.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Well, this is bold work for a privateer to give battle to a King's ſhip.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Try your charge, Sir, and take your ground.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p:
I woud'n't wiſh to ſink, burn or deſtroy what I thought was built for good ſervice, but dam'me if I don't bring wing to you, to teach you better
manners; ſo take care, or I'll put ſome red on your noſe.

div.stage: Enter three Men, without ſeeing Rover.

sp.speaker: 1ſt SAIL.
sp.p: Ah, here's the honeſt fellow has brought us ſome caſh.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: We're betray'd, it's the very gentleman that's in purſuit of of us, and this promiſe was only a decoy to throw us into his power—the piſtol! (aſide)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Good charge (trying the charge, the men ruſh forward, and one of them ſmacks the piſtols from him.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Ha, boys!

sp.speaker: 2nd SAIL.
sp.p: You'd have our lives, and we'll have yours. (Rover runs to his aſſiſtance, and knocks the piſtol out of his hand—they run off.)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Raſcals! (purſues them.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: (takes up the piſtol.) My brave lad I'll — (going,)

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: No, you ſhan't. (ſtops him.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: The rogues will—

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Never mind the rogues. (a piſtol fired without.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: S'blood, muſt I ſee my preſerver periſh? ſtruggling.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I'm your preſerver, and I will periſh, but I'll bring you out of harm's way,

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Tho' he'd fight me himſelf—

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: We all know you'd fight the very devil.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: He ſav'd my life.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I'll ſave your life— (whips him up) —hawl up, my noble little jolly-boat.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Boy, go on with the inventory.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: How unlucky, feyther, to lay hold on me, when I wanted to practice my part.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: This proceeding is too ſevere—to lay an execution on my wretched trifling goods, when I thought—

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Aye, you've gone up to the big houſe with your complaint—her Ladyſhip's ſteward, to be ſure, has made me give back your cottage and farm, but your goods I ſeized for my rent.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Leave me but a few neceſſaries; by my own labour, and the goodneſs of my neighbours, I may ſoon redeem what the law has put in your hands.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: The affair is now in my lawyer's hands, and plaintiff and defendant chattering about it is all ſmoke.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Feyther, don't be ſo cruel to Mr. Banks.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: I'll mark what I may want for myſelf—ſtay you and ſee that not a pin's point be removed. Exit.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: (tearing the paper) Dam'me, if I'll be a watch dog to bite the poor, that I won't. Mr. Banks, as my feyther intends to put up your goods to auction, if you could but get a friend to buy the choice of them for you again; ſiſter Jane has got ſteward to advance her a quarter's wages, and when I've gone to ſell corn for feyther, I've made a market penny now and then —it is'n't much, but every little helps. (offers a leather purſe)

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: I thank you, my good natured boy, but keep your money.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: I remember, about eight year ago you ſav'd me from being drown'd at Black Poole—if you'll not take this, I'll fling it into Black Poole directly.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: My kind lad, I'll not hurt your feelings, by oppoſing your liberality. (takes the purſe)

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: He, he, he!—He's given my heart ſuch pleaſure, as I never felt, nor I'm ſure my feyther before me.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: But, Sim, whatever may be his opinion of worldly prudence, ſtill remember he's your parent.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: I will—One elbow chair, one claw table. (crying out) Exit.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: The confuſion into which Lady Amaranth's family is thrown, by the ſudden departure and apprehended danger of her young couſin, muſt have prevented her Ladyſhip from giving that attention to our affairs that I'm ſure was her inclination—if I can but prevail on my brother to accept of her protection —Heavens, what's this?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: (panting, as out of breath.) What a race— I've got clear of thoſe blood-hounds at laſt; if Abrawang had but followed and back'd me, we'd have tickled their cataſtrophe, but three to one is odds, ſo ſafe's the word. Who's houſe is this I've run into— the friendly cottage of my hoſpitable old gentleman— are you at home? (calls) I had a hard ſtruggle for it, murder was certainly their intent—it was well for me I was born without brains—I'm quite weak and faint.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p:
(comes forward.)
Sir, a'n't you well?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Madam, I aſk your pardon—yes, Madam, very well, I thank you, now exceedingly well—got into a kind of rumpus with ſome worthy gentlemen— not gentlemen, but ſimple farmers, who miſtook me, I fancy, for a ſheath of barley, for they had me down, and their flails flew merrily about my ears, but I got up, and when I could no longer fight like a maſtiff, I run like a greyhound—but, dear Madam, pray excuſe me—this is very rude, faith.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: You ſeem diſturb'd, will you take any refreſhment?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Madam, you're very good—only a glaſs of ſome currant wine, if you pleaſe; I think it ſtands ſomewhere thereabouts. (Ame. fetches a bottle and glaſs) Madam, I've the honor of drinking your health.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: I hope you're not hurt, Sir.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p:
A little better, but very faint ſtill; I had a ſample of this before, and lik'd it ſo much that Ma'am won't you take another? (ſhe declines.) Ma'am if you'd
been fighting as I have, you'd be glad of a drop (drinks again.) Now I'm as well as any man in Illyria—got a few hard knocks, tho'.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: You'd better repoſe a little, you ſeem'd much diſordered coming in.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Why Madam you muſt know that it was—

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: Come Ma'am, Mr. Gammon wants this chair to make up the half dozen above.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: What's all this?

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: Why, the furniture's ſeiz'd on execution, and a man muſt do his duty.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Then ſcoundrel know, that a man's firſt duty is civility and tenderneſs to a woman.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Heaven's where's my brother, this gentleman will bring himſelf into trouble.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: Maſter, d'ye ſee, I'm repreſentative for his honor the High Sheriff.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Every High Sheriff ſhould be a gentleman, and when he's repreſented by a raſcal, he's diſhonored; damn it, I might as well live about Covent Garden, and every night get beating the watch, for here among groves and meadows, I'm always ſquabling with conſtables.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: Come, come, I muſt— (ſits down.)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: As you ſay Sir, laſt Wedneſday ſo it was, Sir, your moſt obedient humble ſervant, pray, Sir, have you ever been aſtoniſhed?

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Becauſe Sir, I intend to aſtoniſh you, (Takes a ſtick off a table and heats him.) Now Sir, are you aſtoniſhed?

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: Yes, but ſee if I don't ſuit you with an action.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Right—ſuit the action to the word, and the word to the action. See if the gentleman be not affrighted, damme, but I'll make thee an example.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: A fine example when goods are ſeized by the law.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Thou worm and maggot of the law, hop me over every kennel houſe, or you ſhall hop without my cuſtom.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: I don't value your cuſtom.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I have aſtoniſh'd, now I'll amaze you.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: No Sir, I won't be amazed, but ſee if I don't.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Hop! [Exit Officer threatening] Madam theſe ſort of gentry, are but bad company for a lady, ſo I'll juſt ſee him to the door—Ma'am I'm your moſt humble ſervant. Exit.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: I feel a ſtrange kind of curioſity to know who this young gentleman is. I find my hear intereſted, I can't account for it; he muſt know the houſe by the freedom he took: but then his gaiety, (without familiar rudeneſs) elegance of manners and good breeding, ſeem to make him at home every where— my brother I think muſt know him.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Amelia, did you ſee the young gentleman that was here?—ſome ruffians have bound and dragg'd him from the door, on the allegation of three men who means to ſwear he has robbed them, and have taken him to Lady Amaranth's.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: How! he did enter in confuſion as if purſued, but I'll ſtake my life on his innocence, I'll ſpeak to her Ladyſhip, and in ſpite of calumny he ſhall have juſtice; he wou'dn't let me be inſulted, becauſe he ſaw me an unprotected woman, without a husband or a ſon and ſhall he want an advocate brother? come—

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p:
I believe there is no ſoul in the houſe but myſelf; my Lady has ſent all the folks round the country, to ſearch after the young 'Squire; ſhe'll certainly break her heart if any thing happens to him. I dont wonder, for ſure he's a dear ſweet gentleman. His going has ſpoiled our play, and I had almoſt got
my part by heart, but muſt, muſt go and do up the room for Mr. Banks's ſiſter, whom my Lady has invited here—

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: The man John Dory hath carried the man George here in his arms, and he locked him up; coming in they did look, like a blue lobſter with a ſhrimp in its claw. Here is the damſel I love alone.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: They ſay when folks look in the glaſs, they ſee the black gentleman. [Looks in a glaſs.] La, there he is!

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Thou art employed in vanity. [Look's over her ſhoulder.]

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Well, who are you?

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: It's natural for woman to love man.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Yea, but not ſuch ugly men as you are, why did you come in to frighten me? when you know there's nobody here but ourſelves.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I'm glad of that; I'm the elm, and thou'rt the honey-ſuckle, let thine arms entwine me.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: What a rogue is here, but yonder comes my Lady. Ill ſhew him off in his true colours. Aſide.

sp.speaker: EHH.
sp.p: Cla •• me round.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: I will, if you will pull off your hat and make me a low bow.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I cannot bend my body, nor take off my beaver.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Then you're very impudent, go along.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: To win thy favor. [moves his hat.]

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Well, now read me a ſpeech out of that fine play book.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Read a play book! abo-mi-nation! but wilt thou kiſs me?

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: I Kiſs a man! abomination, but you may take my hand.

sp.speaker: EPH,
sp.p: Oh, 'tis a comfort to the lip of the faithful. [Kiſſes her hand.]

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p:
How! (
• aps him on the ſhoulder) Ah, thou ſly and deceitful hypocrite!

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Verily Mary I was buffetted by Satan in the ſhape of a damſel.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Begone,

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: My ſpirit is ſad tho' I move ſo nimbly,

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: But oh, heavens! no tidings of my deareſt Harry, Jane, let them renew their ſearch.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Here's Madam Amelia—but I'll make brother Sim look for the young 'Squire. Exit.

sp.speaker: AME,
sp.p: Oh, Madam might I implore your influence with—

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Thou art ill accomodated here, but I hope thou wilt excuſe it, my mind is a ſea of trouble, my peace is ſhipwrecked! Oh, had'ſt thou ſeen my Couſin Harry! all who know him muſt be anxious for his ſafety! how unlucky, this ſervant to prevent Sir George from giving him that aſſiſtance, which paternal cares and indeed gratitude demanded, for 'twas filial affection bade him to purſue thoſe wicked men, callous to every feeling of humanity—they may—yes my Henry in the opening bud of manlineſs is nipp'd!

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Heave a-head. [John without.]

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Raſcal, whip me up like a pound of tea, dance about like a young bear! make me quit the preſerver of my life, yes, puppy unknown will think me a paltroon, and that I was afraid to follow and ſecond him.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: You may as well turn into your hammock, for out to night you ſhall not go. (Sees Amelia) Mercy of heaven is'n't it—only look.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: 'Tis my Amelia.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Reef your foreſail firſt, you crack'd her heart by ſheering off, and now you'll overſet her by bringing to.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Are you at length return'd to me, my Seymour?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Seymour!—her mind's diſturbed—this is mine uncle, Sir George Thunder.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: No, no, my Lady, ſhe knows what ſhe's ſaying, well enough.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Niece, I have been a villain to this lady, I confeſs; but, my dear Amelia, providence has done you juſtice in part; for from the firſt month I quitted you, I have never entered one happy hour on my journals—hearing that you foundered, and conſidering myſelf the cauſe, the worm of remorſe has knaw'd my timbers.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: You're not ſtill offended with me.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Me—can you forgive me my offence, and condeſcend to take my hand as an atonement?

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Your hand—do you forget we're already married?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Aye, there was my raſcality.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: You may ſay that.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: That marriage, my dear, I'm aſhamed to own it—but it was—

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: As good as if done by the chaplain of the Eagle.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, you impudent crimp, you • pandar, you bad adviſer—I'll ſtrike my falſe colours, I'll acknowledge the chaplain you provided was—

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: A good man, and a greater honor to his black, than your honor has been to your blue cloth; by the word of a ſeaman, here he is himſelf.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Your brother!

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Capt. Seymour! have I found you, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: My dear Banks, I'll make every reparation—Amelia ſhall really be my wife.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: That, Sir, my ſiſter is already; for when I performed the marriage ceremony, which you took only as a cloak of your deception, I was actually in orders.

sp.speaker: JOHN,.
sp.p:
Now who's the crimp and the pandar?— I never told you this, becauſe I thought a man's own
reflections were the beſt puniſhment for betraying an innocent woman.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: (to John.) You ſhall be a poſt captain for this, ſink me, if you ſhan't.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Madam, my inmoſt ſoul partaketh of thy gladneſs and joy for thy reformation: (to Sir Geo.) but thy prior marriage to this lady annuls the ſubſequent, and my couſin Harry is not now thine heir.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: So much the better, he's an unnatural cub—but, Amelia, I flatter myſelf I have an heir— my infant boy.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Ha, husband, you had, but—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Gone—well, well, I ſee I have been a miſerable ſcoundrel—I'll adopt that brave kind lad, that wou'd'n't let any body kill me but himſelf, he ſhall have my eſtate, that's my own acquſition—my lady marrying him—Puppy Unknown's a fine fellow! Amelia, only for him, you'd never have found your husband.—Captain Seymour is Sir George Thunder.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Are you Sir George Thunder.

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: Pleaſe you, Madam, they have got a foot-pad in cuſtody.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I'm come to ſit in judgment, for there is a bad man in thy houſe, Mary—bring him before me.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Before you, old Squintabus! perhaps you don't know I'm a magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I'll examine him.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: You be damn'd; I'll examine him myſelf—tow him in here, I'll give him a paſſport to Wincheſter bilbows.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: (kneels to Sir Geo.) Oh, Sir, as you hope for mercy, extend it to this youth, and even ſhould he be guilty, which from our knowledge of his benevolent and noble nature, I think next to an impoſſibility, let the ſervices he has rendered us plead for him—he protected your forſaken wife, and her unhappy brother, in the hour of want and ſorrow.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What, Amelia plead for a robber!— conſider my love, Juſtice is above bias or partiality; if my ſon violated the laws of his country. I'd deliver him up as a public victim to diſgrace and puniſhment.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Oh, my impartial uncle! Had thy country any laws to puniſh him, who inſtead of paltry gold, would rob the artleſs virgin of her deareſt treaſure, in the rigid judge, I ſhould now behold the trembling criminal.

div.stage: Enter TWITCH, with two men, and ROVER bound.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Speak thou—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Hold thy clapper, thou—you wretched perſon, who are the proſecutors.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Call in—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p:
Will nobody ſtop his mouth
(John carries him up the ſtage.) Where are the proſecutors?

sp.speaker: TWITCH,
sp.p: There, tell his worſhip the juſtice.

sp.speaker: 1ſt MAN.
sp.p: A juſtice—oh, the devil!—I thought we ſhould have nothing but quakers to deal with (aſide)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Come, how did this fellow rob you?

sp.speaker: 1ſt MAN.
sp.p: Why, your honour, I ſwear—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Oh, ho!

sp.speaker: 1ſt MAN.
sp.p: Zounds, we're in the wrong, this is the very—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Clap down the hatches, ſecure theſe ſharks.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I'm glad to find you here, Abrawang, as I believe you have ſome knowledge of theſe gentlemen.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Heaven's, my couſin Harry!

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: The Devil! is'n't that my ſpear and ſhield?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: My young maſter, what have you been at • ere, (unbinds him,) this rope may be wanted yet.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: My dear fellow are you ſafe?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Yes, Dick, I was brought here very ſafe, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: A confederate in cuſtody has made a confeſſion of their villainy, that they concerted this plan to accuſe him of a robbery, firſt for revenge, then in hopes to ſhare the reward for apprehending him; he alſo owns they are not ſailors but depredators on the public.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What, could you find no jacket to diſgrace by your wearing than that of an Engliſh Seamen— a character, whoſe bravery is even the admiration of his enemies, and genuine honeſty of heart, the glory of human nature? Keep them ſafe.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Aye, I knew the rope would be wanted, (drives them off.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Not knowing that the Juſtice of Peace whom they brought the lad before, is the very man they attacked, ha, ha, ha! the rogues have fallen into their own ſnare.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: What now you're a Juſtice of Peace?—well ſaid, Abrawang.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Then, Sir George you know him too?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Know him! to be ſure I do.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Still Sir George—what then you will not reſign your Knighthood! Madam, I'm happy to ſee you again. Ah, how do you do, my kind hoſt? (to Banks)

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I rejoice at thy ſafety, be reconcil'd to him. (To Sir George)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Reconcil'd! if I don't love, reſpect and honor him, I ſhould be unworthy of the life he reſcued —but who is he?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Sir, he is—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Dick, I thank you for your good wiſhes, but I'm ſtill determined not to impoſe on this Lady. Madam, as I firſt told that well-meaning tar, when he forc'd me to your houſe, I'm not the ſon of Sir George Thunder.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Then I wiſh you was the ſon of an Admiral, and I your father.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You refuſe the lady—to puniſh you, I have a mind to take her myſelf, my dear Couſin.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Stop Dick, if I who adore her won't, you ſhall not; no, no, Madam, never mind what the fellow ſays, he's as poor as myſelf, is'n't he Abrawang?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Then my dear Rover, ſince you are ſo obſtinately interreſted, I'll no longer teize my father, whom you here ſee, and in your ſtrolling friend, his very truant Harry that ran from Portſmoth Academy, and joined you and fellow Comedians.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Dear couſin forgive me, if thro' my zeal for the happineſs of my friend, I endeavoured to promote your's, by giving you a husband, more worthy than myſelf.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Am I to believe, Madam, is your uncle Sir George Thunder in the room?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: He is.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: 'Tis you in reality; what I've had the impudence to aſſume, and have perplex'd your father with my ridiculous effrontery. I told you (to John) I was not the perſon you took me for, but you muſt bring your damn'd chariot—I am aſham'd and mortified—Madam, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Thou art welcome to go.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Sir George, as the father of my friend, I cannot lift my hand againſt you, but I hope, Sir, you'll apoligize to me apart.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Aye, with pleaſure, my noble ſplinter. Now tell me from what dock you were launch'd, my heart of oak?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I heard in England, Sir; but from my earlieſt knowledge, till within a few years I've been in the Eaſt Indies.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Beyond ſeas—well, and how?

sp.speaker: ROV
sp.p: It ſeems I was committed an infant to the care of a lady, who was herſelf obliged by the gentle Hyder Ally to ſtrike her toilet, and decamp without beat of drum, leaving me a chubby little fellow, ſquatted on a carpet; a ſerjant's wife alone returned, and ſnatched me off triumphant, thro' fire, ſmoke, cannon, cries, and carnage.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: (To Amelia) Doſt thou mark?

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Sir, can you recollect the name of the town where—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Yes Madam, the town was Negapatam.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: An officer, who had much rather act Hotſpur on the ſtage, than in the field, brought me up behind the ſcenes at Calcutta theatre; I was enroll'd on the boards, acted myſelf into the favour of a colonel, promiſed a pair of colours; but impatient to find my parents, hid myſelf in the ſteerage of a homewardbound ſhip, aſſumed the name of Rover, from the uncertainty of my ſate, and have murdered more Poets, than Rajahs, ſtopped on Engliſh ground unincumbered with rupees or pagodas.—Ha, ha, ha, wouldſt'ſt thou have come home ſo, little Ephraim?

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I would bring myſelf home with ſome money.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Excuſe my curioſity, Sir—what was the lady's name in whoſe care you was left?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, ſhe was the lady of a Major Linſtock, but I heard my mother's name was Seymour.

sp.speaker: SIR. GEO.
sp.p: Why, Amelia!

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: My ſon!

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: It is my Charles. (embraces him)

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Tol de rol!— (dances a hornpipe ſtep) —Tho' I never heard it before, my heart told me he was a chip of the old block. Your father (to Rover, and points to Sir Geo.)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Can it—

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Yes, my ſon, Sir George Thunder here is Captain Seymour, in ſearch of whom you may have heard I quitted England.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Heavens, then have I attempted to raiſe my hands againſt a parent's life.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: My brave boy—then have I a ſon with ſpirit to fight me as a ſailor, yet defend me as a father.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Uncle, you'll recollect 'twas I firſt introduced this ſon to thee.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: And I hope you'll next introduce a grandſon to me, young Slyboots.—Harry, you have loſt your fortune.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—but I've gained a brother, whoſe friendſhip, before I knew him to be ſuch, I prized before the firſt fortune in England.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: My deareſt Roſalind.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Then, you will take our Charles?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Yea; but only on conditions, thou beſtow thy fortune on his friend and brother—mine is ſufficient for us both, is it not?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Angelic creature! to think of my generous friend. But now for As You Like It; where's Lamp and Trap! I ſhall ever love a play; a ſpark from Shakeſpeare's muſe of fire, was the ſtar that guided me through my deſolate and bewildered maze of life, and brought me to theſe unexpected bleſſings.

lg.l: To merit friends ſo good, ſo ſweet a wife,
The tender husband be my part for life.
My Wild Oats ſown, let candid Theſpian laws
Decree that glorious harveſt—your applauſe.

div.p: LIONEL and CLARISSA: OR, THE SCHOOL FOR FATHERS. A COMIC OPERA. WRITTEN BY MR. BICKERSTAFF. MARKED WITH THE VARIATIONS IN THE MANAGER'S BOOK AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
PHILADELPHIA. PRINTED BY W. W. WOODWARD, FOR MATHEW CAREY, No. •• 8, Market-ſtreet. 1794.
*⁎*THE Reader is deſired to obſerve, that the Paſſages omitted in the repreſentation at the Theatre, are here preſerved, and marked with inverted commas; as in line 1 to 15, page 14.

div.head: Advertiſement.
div.p: HAVING, for ſome years, • et with very great ſucceſs in my productions of the muſical kind; when I wrote the following Opera, it was with unuſual care and attention; and it was the general opinion of all my friends, ſome of whom rank among the beſt judges, that of all my trifles, Lionel and Clariſſa was the moſt pardonable: a deciſion in its favour, which I was the prouder of, becauſe, to the beſt of my knowledge, through the whole, I had not borrowed an expreſſion, a ſentiment, or a character, from any dramatic writer extant.

When Mr. GARRICK thought of performing this piece at Drury-lane theatre, he had a new ſinger to bring out, and every thing poſſible for her advantage was to be done; this neceſſarily occaſioned ſome new ſongs and airs to be introduced; and other ſingers, with voices of a different compaſs from thoſe who originally acted the parts, occaſioned ſtill more; by which means the greateſt part of the muſic unavoidably became new. This is the chief, and indeed the only alteration made in the Opera: and even to that, I ſhould in many places have been forced, much againſt my will, had it not given a freſh opportunity to Mr. Dibden to diſplay his admirable talents as a muſical compoſer. And I will be bold to ſay, that his airs, ſerious and comic, in this Opera, will appear to no diſadvantage by being heard with thoſe of ſome of the greateſt maſters.
The SCHOOL FOR FATHERS is added to the title, becauſe the plot in evidently double; and that of Lionel and Clariſſa alluded to but one part of it, as the readers and ſpectators will eaſily perceive.

postscript.p: P. S. The SONGS varying from thoſe performed at Drury-lane, are inſerted at the end.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: SCENE, A Chamber in Colonel Oldboy's Houſe: Colonel Oldboy at breakfaſt, reading a newſpaper; at a little diſtance ſits Jenkins; and on the oppoſite ſide, Diana, playing upon a harpſichord. A Girl attending.

lg.l: AH how delightful the morning,

l.hi: How ſweet are the proſpects it yields!
The gardens, the groves, and the fields.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Dy; thank you, Dy. This, maſter Jenkins, is the way I make my daughter entertain me every morning at breakfaſt. Come here and kiſs me, you ſlut; come here and kiſs me, you baggage.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Lord, papa, you call one ſuch names—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A fine girl, maſter Jenkins, a deviliſh fine girl! ſhe has got my eye to a twinkle. There's fire for you!— ſpirit!—I deſign to marry her to a Duke; how much money do you think a Duke would expect with ſuch a wench?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Why, Colonel, with ſubmiſſion, I think there is no occaſion to go out of our own country here; we have never a Duke in it, I believe; but we have many an honeſt gentleman, who, in my opinion, might deſerve the young lady.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: So you would have me marry Dy to a country Squire, eh! How ſay you to this, Dy? Would not you rather be married to a Duke?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: So my huſband's a rake, papa, I don't care what he is.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A rake! you damned confounded little baggage; why, you would not wiſh to marry a rake, would you? So her huſband is a rake, ſhe does not care what he is!— Ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Well, but liſten to me, papa—When you go out with your gun, do you take any pleaſure in ſhooting the poor tame ducks and chickens in your yard? No, the partridge, the pheaſant, the woodcock, are the game; there is ſome ſport in bringing them down, becauſe they are wild; and it is juſt the ſame with an huſband or a lover. I would not waſte powder and ſhot to wound one of your ſober pretty behaved gentlemen; but to hit a libertine, extravagant, madcap fellow, to take him upon the wing—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Do you hear her, maſter Jenkins? Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Well, but good Colonel, what do you ſay to my worthy and honorable patron here, Sir John Flowerdale? He has an eſtate of eight thouſand pounds a year as well, paid rents as any in the kingdom, and but one only daughter to enjoy it; and yet he is willing, you ſee, to give this daughter to your ſon.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Jenkins, how does Miſs Clariſſa and our univerſity friend, Mr. Lionel? That is the only grave young man I ever liked, and the only handſome one I ever was acquainted with, that did not make love to me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, maſter Jenkins, who is this Lionel? They ſay he is a damned witty, knowing fellow; and egad I think him well enough for one brought up in a college.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p:
His father was a general officer, a particular friend of Sir John's, who, like many more brave men that live and die in defending their country, left little elſe than honour behind him▪ Sir John ſent this young man, at his own expence, to Oxford; where, while his ſon lived, they were upon the ſame footing: and ſince our young gentleman's death, which you know unfortunately happened about two years ago, he has continued him there. During the vacation he is come to pay us a viſit, and Sir John intends that he ſhall ſhortly take orders for a very
conſiderable benefice in the gift of the family, the preſent incumbent of which is an aged man.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: The laſt time I was at your houſe, he was teaching Miſs Clariſſa mathematics and philoſophy. Lord! what a ſtrange brain I have! If I was to ſit down to diſtract myſelf with ſuch ſtudies—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Go, huſſey, let ſome of your brother's raſcals inform their maſter that he has been long enough at his toilet; here is a meſſage from Sir John Flowerdale— You a brain for mathematics, indeed! we ſhall have women wanting to head our regiments to-morrow or next day.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Well, papa, and ſuppoſe we did. I believe, in a battle of the ſexes, you men would hardly get the better of us.

lg.l: To rob them of ſtrength, when wiſe nature thought fit
By women to ſtill do her duty,
Inſtead of a ſword, ſhe endues them with wit,
And gave them a ſhield in ther beauty.
Sound, ſound then the trumpet, both ſexes to arms!
Our tyrants at once and protectors!
We quickly ſhall ſee, whether courage or charms
Decide for the Helens or Hectors. Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, maſter Jenkins! don't you think now that a nobleman, a Duke, an Earl, or a Marquis, might be content to ſhare his title—I ſay, you underſtand me—with a ſweetener of thirty or forty thouſand pounds, to pay off mortgages? Beſides, there's a proſpect of my whole eſtate; for, I dare ſwear her brother will never have any children.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I ſhould be concerned at that, Colonel, when there are two ſuch fortunes to deſcend to his heirs, as yours and Sir John Flowerdale's.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Why, look you, maſter Jenkins, Sir John Flowerdale is an honeſt gentleman; our families are nearly related; we have been neighbours time out of mind; and if he and I have an odd diſpute now and then, it is not for
want of a cordial eſteem at bottom. He is going to marry his daughter to my ſon; ſhe is a beautiful girl, an elegant girl, a ſenſible girl, a worthy girl, and—a word in your ear—damn me, it I an't very ſorry for her.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Sorry! Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay—between ourſelves, maſter Jenkins, my ſon won't do.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I tell you, maſter Jenkins, he won't do—he is not the thing, a prig—At ſixteen years old, or thereabouts, he was a bold ſprightly boy, as you ſhould ſee in a thouſand; could drink his pint of port, or his bottle of claret —now he mixes all his wine with water.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Oh! if that be his only fault, Colonel, he will ne • er make the worſe huſband, I'll anſwer for it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You know my wife is a woman of quality—I was prevailed upon to ſend him to be brought up by her brother Lord J •• ſamy, who had no children of his own, and promiſed to leave him an eſtate—He has got the eſtate indeed, but the fellow has taken his Lordſhip's name for it. Now, maſter Jenkins, I would be glad to know how the name of Jeſſamy is better than that of Oldboy?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Well! but, Colonel, it is allowed on all hands, that his Lordſhip has given your ſon an excellent education.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Pſha! he ſent him to the univerſity, and to travel, for ſooth; but, what of that? I was abroad, and at the univerſity myſelf, and never a ruſh the better for either. I quarrelled with his Lordſhip about ſix years before his death, and ſo had not an opportunity of ſeeing how the youth went on; if I had, maſter Jenkins, I would no more have ſuffered him to be made ſuch a monkey of— He has been in my houſe but three days, and it is all turned topſey-turvey by him and his raſcally ſervants— then his chamber is like a perfumer's ſhop, with waſh-balls, paſtes, and pomatum—and do you know he had the impudence to tell me yeſterday at my own table, that I did not know how to behave myſelf.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Pray, Colonel, how does my Lady Mary?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What, my wife? In the old way, maſter Jenkins; always complaining; ever ſomething the matter with her head, or her back, or her legs—but we have had the devil to pay lately—ſhe and I did not ſpeak to one another for three weeks.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: How ſo, ſir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A little affair of jealouſy—You moſt know, my game-keeper's daughter has had a child, and the plaguy baggage takes it into her head to lay it to me—Upon my ſoul, it is a fine fat chubby infant, as ever I ſet my eyes on; I have ſent it to nurſe; and, between you and me, I believe I ſhall leave it a fortune.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Ah, Colonel, you will never give over.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You know my Lady has a pretty vein of poetry; ſhe writ me an heroic epiſtle upon it, where ſhe calls me her dear falſe Damon; ſo I let her cry a little, promiſed to do ſo no more, and now we are as good friends as ever.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Well, Colonel, I muſt take my leave; I have delivered my meſſage, and Sir John may expect the pleaſure of your company to dinner.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, ay, we'll come—pox o' ceremony among friends. But won't you ſtay to ſee my ſon; I have ſent to him, and ſuppoſe he will be here as ſoon as his valet-de-chambre will give him leave.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: There's no occaſion, good ſir; preſent my humble reſpects, that's all.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, but, zounds, Jenkins, you muſt not go till you drink ſomething—let you and I have a bottle of hock—

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Not for the world, Colonel; I never touch any thing ſtrong in the morning.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Never touch any thing ſtrong! Why, one bottle won't hurt you, man—this is old, and as mild as milk.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Well, but, Colonel, pray excuſe me.

lg.l: To tell you the truth,
In the days of my youth,
As mirth and nature bid,
I lik'd a glaſs,
And I lov'd a laſs.
And I did as younkers did.
But now I am old,
With grief be it told,
I muſt thoſe freaks forbear;
At ſixty-three,
'Twixt you and me,
A man grows worſe for wear. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Jeſſamy, and Lady Mary Oldboy.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Shut the door, why don't you ſhut the door there? Have you a mind I ſhould catch my death?— This houſe is abſolutely the cave of Aeo • us; one had as good live on the eddyſtone, or in a wind-mill.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: I thought they told your Ladyſhip that there was a meſſenger here from Sir John Flowerdale?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, ſir, and ſo there was; but he had not patience to wait upon your curling-irons. Mr. Jenkins was here, Sir John Flowerdale's ſteward, who has lived in the family theſe forty years.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: And pray, ſir, might not Sir John Flowerdale have come himſelf? If he had been acquainted with the rules of good breeding, he would have known that I ought to have been viſited.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Upon my word, Colonel, this is a ſoleciſm.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Sblood, my Lady, its none. Sir John Flowerdale came but laſt night from my ſiſter's ſeat in the Weſt, and is a little out of order. But I ſuppoſe he thinks he ought to appear before him with his daughter in one hand, and his rent-roll in the other, and cry, Sir, pray do me the favour to accept them.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Nay, but, Mr. Oldboy, permit me to ſay—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He need not give himſelf ſo many affected airs; I think it's very well if he gets ſuch a girl for going for— ſhe's one of the handſomeſt and richeſt in this country, and more than he deſerves.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p:
That's an exceeding fine china jar your Ladyſhip has got in the next room; I ſaw the fellow of it the other day at Williams's, and will ſend to my agent to purchaſe it; it is the true matchleſs old blue and white. Lady Betty Barebones has a couple that ſhe gave an hundred guineas for, on board an Indiaman; but ſhe reckons them
at a hundred and twenty-five, on account of half a dozen plates, four Nankin beakers, and a couple of ſhading mandarins, that the cuſtom-houſe officers took from under her petticoats.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Did you ever hear the like of this! He's chattering about old china, while I am talking to him of a fine girl. I tell you what, Mr. Jeſſamy, ſince that's the name you chooſe to be called by, I have a good mind to knock you down.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Knock me down, Colonel! What do you mean? I muſt tell you, ſir, this is a language to which I have not been accuſtomed; and if you think proper to continue to repeat it, I ſhall be under a neceſſity of quitting your houſe?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Quitting my houſe?

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, incontinently.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, ſir, am not I your father, ſir? and have I not a right to talk to you as I like? I will, ſirrah. But, perhaps I mayn't be your father, and I hope not.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Heavens and earth, Mr. Oldboy!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What's the matter, madam! I mean, madam, that he might have been changed at nurſe, madam; and I believe he was.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Huh! huh! huh!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Do you laugh at me, you ſaucy jackanapes!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Who's there—ſomebody bring me a chair. Really, Mr. Oldboy, you throw my weakly frame into ſuch repeated convulſions—but I ſee your aim; you want to lay me in my grave, and you will very ſoon have that ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I can't bear the ſight of him.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Open that window, give me air, or I ſhall faint.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Hold, hold, let me tie a handkerchief about my neck firſt. This curſed ſharp north wind—Antoine, bring down my muff.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, do, and his great-coat.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Margaret, ſome hartſharn. My dear Mr. Oldboy, why will you fly out in this way, when you know how it ſhocks my tender nerves?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Sblood, madam, its enough to make a man mad.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Hartſhorn! Hartſhorn!

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Colonel!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Do you hear the puppy?

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Will you give me leave to aſk you one queſtion?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I don't know whether I will or not.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: I ſhould be glad to know, that's all, what ſingle circumſtance in my conduct, carriage, or figure, you can poſſibly find fault with—Perhaps I may be brought to reform—Pr'ythee, let me hear from your own mouth then, ſeriouſly what it is you do like, and what it is you do not like.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hum!

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Be ingenuous, ſpeak and ſpare not.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You would know?

lg.l: Zounds, ſir! then I'll tell you without any jeſt,
The thing of all things which I hate and deteſt;
A coxcomb, a fop,
A dainty milk-ſop;
Who, eſſenc'd and dizen'd from bottom to top,
Looks juſt like a doll for a milliner's ſhop.
A thing full of prate,
And pride and conceit;
All faſhion, no weight;
Who ſhrugs and takes ſnuff,
And carries a muff;
A minikin,
Finiking,
French powder puff:
And now, ſir, I fancy I've told you enough Exit.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: What's the matter with the Colonel, madam; does your Ladyſhip know?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p:
Heigho! don't be ſurpriſed, my dear; it was the ſame thing with my late dear brother, Lord Jeſſamy; they never could agree: that good-natured, friendly ſoul, knowing the delicacy of my conſtitution, has often ſaid, ſiſter Mary, I pity you. Not but your father has good qualities, and, I aſſure you, I remember him a
very fine gentleman himſelf. In the year of the hard froſt, one thouſand ſeven hundred and thirty-nine, when he firſt paid his addreſſes to me, he was called agreeable J • ck O • dboy, though I married him without the conſent of your noble grandfather.
I think he ought to be proud of me: I believe there's many a Duke, nay Prince, who would eſteem themſelves happy in having ſuch a ſon—

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Yes, my dear; but your ſiſter was always your father's favourite: He intends to give her a prodigious fortune, and ſets his heart upon ſeeing her a woman of quality.
He ſhould wiſh to ſee her look a little like a gentlewoman firſt. When ſhe was in London laſt winter, I am told ſhe was taken notice of by a few men. But ſhe wants a • r, manner—

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: And has not a bit of the genius of our family, and I never knew a woman of it, but herſelf, without. I have tried her. About three years ago, I ſet her to tranſlate a little French ſong: I found ſhe had not even an idea of verſification; and ſhe put down love and joy for rhyme—ſo I gave her over.
Why, indeed, ſhe appears to have more of the 'T • ateſtris than the Sappho about her.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Well, my dear, I muſt go and dreſs myſelf, though I proteſt I am fitter for my bed than my coach — And condeſcend to the Colonel a little—Do, my dear, if it be only to oblige your mamma. Exit.

Let me conſider—I am going to viſit a country Baronet here, who would fain prevail upon me to marry his daughter: the old gentleman has heard of my parts and underſtanding; Miſs, of my figure and addreſs — But, ſuppoſe I ſhould not like her when I ſee her?— Why, poſitively, then I will not have her; the treaty's at an end, and, ſans compliment, we break up the congreſs. But, won't that be cruel, after having ſuffered her to flatter herſelf with hopes, and ſhewing myſelf to her. She's a ſtrange dowdy, I dare believe: however, ſhe brings proviſion with her for a ſeparate maintenance.
Antoine, appretez la toilette. I am going to ſpend a curſed day; that I perceive already; I wiſh it was over, I dread it as much as a general election.

lg.l: When a man of faſhion condeſcends
To herd among his country friends,
They watch his looks, his motions:
One booby gapes, another ſtares,
And all he ſays, does, eats, drinks, wears,
Muſt ſuit their ruſtic notions.
But as for this brutiſh old clown here,
'Sdeath, why did I ever come down here!
The ſavage will now never quit me:
Then a conſort to take,
For my family's ſake,
Twix a fair jeopardy, ſp ••• me! Exit,

div.stage: SCENE, a Study in Sir John Flowerdale's Houſe.— Clariſſa enters, followed by Jenny.

l.hi: And let me, let me reſt.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: My dear lady, what ails you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nothing, Jenny; nothing.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Pardon me madam, there is ſomething ails you, indeed. Lord! what ſignifies all the grandeur and riches in this world, if they can't procure one content. I am ſure it vexes me to the heart, ſo it does, to ſee ſuch a dear, ſweet, worthy young lady, as you are, pining yourſelf to death.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Jenny, you are a good girl, and I am very much obliged to you for feeling ſo much on my account; but in a little time, I hope, I ſhall be eaſier.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p:
Why, now, here to day, madam—for certain,
you ought to be merry to-day, when there's a fine gentleman coming to court you, but, if you like any one elſe better, I am ſure, I wiſh you had him, with all my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Suppoſe, Jenny, I was ſo unfortunate as to like a man without my father's approbation—would you wiſh me to marry him?

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I wiſh you married to any one, madam, that could make you happy.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Heigho!

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Madam! madam! yonder's Sir John and Mr. Lionel on the terrace. I believe they are coming up here. Poor, dear, Mr. Lionel, he does not ſeem to be in over great ſpirits either. To be ſure, madam, it's no buſineſs of mine; but, I believe, if the truth was known, there are thoſe in the houſe who would give more than ever I ſhall be worth, or any the likes of me, to prevent the marriage of a certain perſon that ſhall be nameleſs.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What do you mean? I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: I hope you are not angry, madam?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ah! Jenny—

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Lauk, madam! do you think when Mr. Lionel's a clergyman, he'll be obliged to cut off his hair. I'm ſure it will be a thouſand pities, for it is the ſweeteſt colour, and looks the niceſt put up in a queue— and your great pudding-ſleeves! Lord! they'll quite ſpoil his ſhape, and the fall of his ſhoulders. Well! madam, if I was a lady of large fortune, I'll be hanged if Mr. Lionel ſhould be a parſon, if I could help it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'm going into my dreſſing-room— • t ſeems then Mr. Lionel is a great favorite of yours; but pray, Jenny ▪ have a care how you talk in this manner to any one elſe.

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p: Me talk! madam—I thought you knew me better; and, my dear lady, keep up your ſpirits. I'm ſure I have dreſſed you to day as nicely as hands and pins can make you.

lg.l: I'm but a poor ſervant, 'tis true, ma'am;
But was I a lady like you, ma'am,
In grief would I ſit? The dickens a bit;
No, faith, I would ſearch the world through, ma'am,
To find what my liking could hit.
Set in caſe a young man,
In my fancy there ran,
It might anger my friends and relations;
But if I had regard,
It ſhould go very hard,
Or I'd follow my own inclinations. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir John Flowerdale, and Lionel.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Indeed, Lionel, I will not hear of it. What! to run from us all of a ſudden, this way; and at ſuch a time, too; the eve of my daughters wedding, as I may call it, when your company muſt be doubly agreeable, as well as neceſſary to us? I am ſure you have no ſtudies at preſent that require your attendance at Oxford: I muſt therefore inſiſt on your putting ſuch thoughts out of your head.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Upon my word, ſir, I have been ſo long from the univerſity, that it is time for me to think of returning. It is true, I have no abſolute ſtudies; but really, ſir, I ſhall be obliged to you if you will give me leave to go.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come, come, my dear L • onel, I have for ſome time obſerved a more than ordinary gravity growing upon you, and I am not to learn the reaſon of it: I know, to minds ſerious and well inclined, like yours, the ſacred functions you are about to embrace—

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Dear ſir, your goodneſs to me, of every kind, is ſo great, ſo unremitted —Your condeſcenſion, your friendly attentions—in ſhort, ſir, I want words to expreſs my ſenſe of obligations—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, no more of them. By my laſt letters, I find, that my old friend the Rector ſtill continues in good health, conſidering his advanced years. You may imagine, I am far from deſiring the death of
ſo worthy and pious a man; yet, I muſt own, at this time, I could wiſh you were in orders, as you might then perform the ceremony of my daughter's marriage; which would give me a ſecret ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: No doubt, ſir, any office in my power that could be inſtrumental to the happineſs of any in your family, I ſhould perform with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, really, Lionel, from the character of her intended huſband, I have no room to doubt, but this match will make Clariſſa perfectly happy: to be ſure the alliance is the moſt eligible for both families.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: If the gentleman is ſenſible of his happineſs in the alliance, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The fondneſs of a father is always ſuſpected of partiality; yet, I believe, I may venture to ſay, that few young women will be found more unexceptionable than my daughter: her perſon is agreeable, her temper ſweet, her underſtanding good; and, with the obligations ſhe has to your inſtructions—

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: You do my endeavours too much honour, ſir; I have been able to add nothing to Miſs Flowerdale's accompliſhments, but a little knowledge in matters of ſmall importance to a mind already ſo well improved.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I don't think ſo; a little knowledge, even in thoſe matters, is neceſſary for a woman, in whom I am far from conſidering ignorance as a deſireable characteriſtic. When intelligence is not attended with impertinent affectation, it teaches them to judge with preciſion, and gives them a degree of ſolidity neceſſary for the companion of a ſenſible man.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Yonder's Mr. Jenkins: I fancy he's looking for you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I ſee him; he's come back from Colonel Oldboy's; I have a few words to ſay to him, and will return to you again in a minute. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: To be a burthen to one's ſelf, to wage continual war with one's own paſſions; forced to combat, unable to overcome! But ſee, ſhe appears, whoſe preſence turns all my ſufferings into tranſport, and makes even miſery itſelf delightful.
Perhaps, madam, you are not at leiſure now; otherwiſe, if you thought proper, we would reſume the ſubject we were upon yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I am ſure, ſir, I give you a great deal of trouble.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Madam, you give me no trouble; I ſhould think every hour of my life happily employed in your ſervice; and as this is probably the laſt time I ſhall have the ſatisfaction of attending you upon the ſame occaſion—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Upon my word, Mr. Lionel, I think myſelf extremely obliged to you; and ſhall ever conſider the enjoyment of your friendſhip—

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: My friendſhip, madam, can be of little moment to you; but if the moſt perfect adoration, if the warmeſt wiſhes for your felicity, though I ſhould never be witneſs of it—if theſe, madam, can have any merit to continue in your remembrance, a man once honoured with a ſhare of your eſteem—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Hold, ſir—I think I hear ſomebody.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, madam, we will turn over this oeleſtial globe once more—Have you looked at the book I left you yeſterday?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Really, ſir, I have been ſo much diſturbed in my thoughts for theſe two or three days paſt, that I have not been able to look at any thing.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: I am ſorry to hear that, madam; I hope there was nothing particular to diſturb you. The care Sir John takes to diſpoſe of your hand in a manner ſuitable to your birth and fortune—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I don't know, ſir—I own I am diſturbed; I own I am uneaſy; there is ſomething weighs upon my heart, which I would fain diſcloſe.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Upon your heart, madam!—did you ſay your heart?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I did, ſir—I—

sp.speaker: Jen.
sp.p:
Madam! madam! Here's a coach and ſix driving up the avenue: It's Colonel Oldboy's family; and, I believe, the gentleman is in it that's coming to court you.
Lord, I muſt run and have a peep at him out of the window. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Madam, I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why ſo, ſir?—Bleſs me, Mr. Lionel, what's the matter!—You turn pale.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Pray ſpeak to me, ſir—You tremble—Tell me the cauſe of this ſudden change.—How are you?— Where's your diſorder?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Oh fortune! fortune!

lg.l: You aſk me in vain.
Of what ills I complain,
Where harbours the torment I find;
In my head, in my heart,
It invades every part,
And ſubdues both my body and mind.
Each effort I try,
Every med'cine apply,
The pangs of my ſoul to appeaſe;
But, doom'd to endure,
What I mean for a cure,
Turns poiſon, and feeds the diſeaſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: My dear Clariſſa—I'am glad I have found you alone.—For Heaven's ſake, don't let any one break in upon us—and give me leave to ſit down with you a little —I am in ſuch a tremor, ſuch a panic—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Mercy on us, what has happened?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: You may remember, I told you, that when I was laſt winter in London, I was followed by an odious fellow, one Ha • man: I can't ſay but the wretch pleaſed me, though he is but a young brother, and not worth ſixpence; and—in ſhort, when I was leaving town, I promiſed to correſpond with him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Do you think that was prudent?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p:
Madneſs! But this is not the worſt—for, what do you think?—the creature had the aſſurance to write to
me about three weeks ago, deſiring permiſſion to come down and ſpend the ſummer at my father's.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: At your father's!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Ay, who never ſaw him, knows nothing of him, and would as ſoon conſent to my marrying a horſe jockey. He told me a long ſtory of ſome tale he intended to invent, to make my father receive him as an indifferent perſon; and ſome gentlemen in London, he ſaid, would procure him a letter that ſhould give it a face; and he longed to ſee me ſo, he ſaid, he could not live without it; and if he could be permitted but to ſpend a week with me—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well, and what anſwer did you make?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Oh! abuſed him, and refuſed to liſten to any ſuch thing—But—I vow, I tremble while I tell it you— Juſt before we left our houſe, the impudent monſter arrived there, attended by a couple of ſervants, and is now actually coming here with my father.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Upon my word this is a dreadful thing.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Dreadful my dear!—I happened to be at the window as he came into the court, and I declare I had like to have fainted away.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Isn't my Lady below?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Yes, and I muſt run down to her. You'll have my brother here preſently too; he would fain have come in the coach with my mother and me, but my father inſiſted on his walking with him over the fields.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well Diana, with regard to your affair—I think you muſt find ſome method of immediately informing this gentleman, that you conſider the outrage he has committed againſt you in the moſt heinous light, and inſiſt upon his going away directly.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Why, I believe that will be the beſt way—but then he'll be begging my pardon, and aſking to ſtay.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why, then, you muſt tell him poſitively, you won't conſent to it; and if he perſiſts in ſo extravagant a deſign, tell him you'll never ſee him again as long as you live.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Muſt I tell him ſo?

lg.l: Ah! pr'ythee, ſpare me, deareſt creature!
How can you prompt me to ſo much ill-nature?
Kneeling before me,
Should I hear him implore me;
Could I accuſe him,
Could I refuſe him
The boon he ſhould aſk?
Set not a lover the cruel taſk.
No, believe me, my dear,
Was he now ſtanding here,
In ſpite of my frights and alarms,
I might rate him, might ſcold him—
But ſhould ſtill ſtrive to hold him—
And ſink at laſt into his arms. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How eaſy to direct the conduct of others, how hard to regulate our own! I can give my friend advice, while I am conſcious of the ſame indiſcretion in myſelf. Yet is it criminal to know the moſt worthy, moſt amiable man in the world, and not to be inſenſible to his merit? But my father, the kindeſt, beſt of fathers, will he approve the choice I have made? Nay, has he not made another choice for me? And, after all, how can I be ſure that the man I love, loves me again? He never told me ſo; but his looks, his actions, his preſent anxiety, ſufficiently declare, what his delicacy, his generoſity, will not ſuffer him to utter.

lg.l: Hope and fear, alternate riſing,
Strive for empire o'er my heart;
Every peril now deſpiſing,
Now at ev'ry breath I ſtart.
Teach, ye learned ſages, teach me,
How to ſtem this beating tide;
If you've any rules to reach me,
Haſte and be the weak one's guide.
Thus, our trials at a diſtance,
Wiſdom, ſcience, promiſe aid;
But, in need of their aſſiſtance,
We attempt to graſp a ſhade. Exit.

div.stage: SCENE, a Side View of Sir Sohn Flowerdale's.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, and how does my old friend, Dick Rantum, do? I have not ſeen him theſe twelve years: he was an honeſt worthy fellow, as ever breathed; I remember he kept a girl in London, and was curſedly plagued by his wife's relations.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sir Richard was always a man of ſpirit, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But as to this buſineſs of yours, which he tells me of in his letter—I don't ſee much in it—An affair with a citizen's daughter—pinked her brother in a duel— is the fellow likely to die?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why, ſir, we hope not; but as the matter is dubious, and will probably make ſome noiſe, I thought it was better to be for a little time out of the way; when hearing my caſe, Sir Richard Rantum mentioned you; he ſaid, he was ſure you would permit me to remain at your houſe for a few days, and offered me a recommendation.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And there's likely to be a brat in the caſe—And the girl's friends are in buſineſs—I'll tell you what will be the conſequence then—They will be for going to law with you for a maintenance—but, no matter; I'll take the affair in hand for you—make me your ſolicitor; and if you are obliged to pay for a ſingle ſpoonful of pap, I'll be content to father all the children in the Foundling Hoſpital.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You are very kind, ſir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But hold—hark you—you ſay there's money to be had—ſuppoſe you were to marry the wench?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Do you think, ſir, that would be ſo right, after what has happened? Beſides, there's a ſtronger objection—To tell you the truth, I am honorably in love in another place.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh! you are?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, but there are obſtacles—A father—In ſhort, ſir, the miſtreſs of my heart lives in this very county, which makes even my preſent ſituation a little irkſome.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: In this county! Zounds! Then I am ſure I am acquainted with her; and the firſt letter of her name is—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Excuſe me, ſir, I have ſome particular reaſons.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But, look—who comes yonder?—Ha! ha! ha! My ſon, picking his ſteps like a dancing-maſter. Pr'ythee, Harman, go into the houſe, and let my wife and daughter know we are come, while I go and have ſome ſport with him: they will introduce you to Sir John Flowerdale.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Then, ſir, I'll take the liberty—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But, d'ye hear?—I muſt have a little more diſcourſe with you about this girl; perhaps ſhe is a neighbour of mine, and I may be of ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Well, remember, Colonel, I ſhall try your friendſhip.

lg.l: Indulgent powers, if ever
You mark'd a tender vow,
O bend in kind compaſſion,
And hear a lover now.
For titles, wealth and honours,
While others crowd your ſhrine;
I aſk this only bleſſing,
Let her I love be mine.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, zounds! one would think you had never put your feet to the ground before; you make as much work about walking a quarter of a mile, as if you had gone a pilgrimage to Jeruſalem.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Colonel, you have uſed me extremely ill, to drag me through the dirty roads in this manner; you told me the way was all over a bowling-green; only ſee what a condition I am in!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, how did I know the roads were dirty? is that my fault? Beſides, we miſtook the way. Zounds, man, your legs will never be the worſe when they are bruſhed a little.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Antoine! have you ſent La Roque for the ſhoes and ſtockings? Give me the glaſs out of your pocket: not a duſt of powder left in my hair, and the friſſure as flat as the foretop of an attorney's clerk—get your comb and pomatum; you muſt borrow ſome powder; I ſuppoſe there's ſuch a thing as a dreſſing-room in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, and a cellar too, I hope; for I want a glaſs of wine, curſedly—but, hold! hold! Frank, where are you going? Stay, and pay your devoirs here, if you pleaſe; I ſee there's ſomebody coming out to welcome us.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Colonel, your moſt obedient, Sir John is walking with my Lady in the garden, and has commiſſioned me to receive you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Mr. Lionel, I am heartily glad to ſee you—come here, Frank—this is my ſon, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.p: Sir, I am exceeding proud to—

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Can't you get the powder then?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Miſs Clary, my little Miſs Clary—give me a kiſs, my dear—as handſome as an angel, by Heavens—Frank, why don't you come here? This is Miſs Flowerdale.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens, Clariſſa! Juſt as I ſaid, that impudent devil is come here with my father. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jeſ.
sp.p: Hadn't we better go into the houſe?

lg.l: To be made in ſuch a pickle!
