sp.p: Well, I thought it would come to this, I'll be ſhot if I didn't—'So, here's a fine job'—But what can they do to me?—They can't ſend me to jail for carrying a letter, ſeeing there was no treaſon it; and how was I obligated to know my maſter did not allow of their meetings?—The worſt they can do to me is to turn me off, and I am ſure the place is no ſuch great purchaſe—indeed, I ſhould be ſorry to leave Mrs. Roſetta, ſeeing as how matters are ſo near being bro't to an end betwixt us; 'but ſhe and I may keep company all as one;' and I find Madge has been ſpeaking with Gaffes Broadwheels, the waggoner, about her carriage up to London: ſo that I have got rid of ſhe, and I am ſure I have reaſon to be main glad of it, for ſhe led me a weariſome life—But that's the way of them all.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: A plague on thoſe wenches, they make ſuch a pother,
When once they have let'n a man have his will;
They're always a whining for ſomething or other,
And cry he's unkind in his carriage.
What tho'f he ſpeak them ne'er ſo fairly,
Still they keep teazing, teazing on;
You cannot perſuade 'em,
Till promiſe you've made 'em;
And after they've got it,
They'll tell you—add rot it,
Their character's blaſted, they're ruin'd, undone:
And then to be ſure, ſir,
There is but one cure, ſir.
And all their diſcourſe is of marriage. Exit.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p:
I am glad I had the precaution to bring this ſuit of cloaths in my bundle, though I hardly know myſelf in them again, they appear ſo ſtrange, and feel ſo unwieldy. However, my gardener's jacket goes on no more.—I wonder this girl does not come▪ [looking at his watch] perhaps ſhe won't come—Why then I'll go into the village, take a poſt-chaiſe, and depart without any farther ceremony.
AIR.
How much ſuperior beauty awes,
The coldeſt boſoms find:
But with reſiſtleſs force it draws,
To ſenſe and ſweetneſs join'd.
The caſket, where, to outward ſhow,
The workman's art is ſeen,
Is doubly valu'd, 'when we know
It holds a gem within.
Hark! ſhe comes.

div.stage: Enter Sir William Meadows and Hawthorn.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Confuſion! my father? What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Will,
sp.p: Tom, are not you a ſad boy, Tom, to bring me a hundred and forty miles here—May I never do an ill turn, but you deſerve to have your head broke; and I have a good mind, partly—What, ſirrah, don't you think it worth your while to ſpeak to me?

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: 'Forgive me,' ſir; I own I have been in a fault.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
In a fault! to run away from me becauſe I was going to do you good.—Maſter Hawthorn, may I never do an ill turn, if I did not pick but as fine a girl for him, partly, as any in England; and the raſcal run
away from me, and came here and turn'd gardener. And pray what did you propoſe to yourſelf, Tom? I know you were always fond of botany, as they call it; did you intend to keep the trade going, and advertiſe fruit-trees and flowering-ſhrubs, to be had at Meadows's nurſery?

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: No, Sir William, I apprehend the young gentleman deſigned to lay by the profeſſion; for he has quitted the habit already.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: I am ſo aſtoniſhed to ſee you here, ſir, that I don't know what to ſay; but 'I aſſure you,' if you had not come, I ſhould have returned home to you directly. Pray, ſir, how did you find me out?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No matter, Tom, no matter; it was partly by accident, as a body may ſay; but what does that ſignify—Tell me, boy, how ſtands your ſtomach towards matrimony; do you think you could digeſt a wife now?

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, don't mention it: I ſhall always behave myſelf as a dutiful ſon ought; I will never marry without your conſent, and I hope you won't force me to do it againſt my own.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Is not this mighty provoking, maſter Hawthorn? Why, ſirrah, did you ever ſee the lady I deſigned for you?

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Sir, I don't doubt the lady's merit; but at preſent I am not diſpoſed—

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Nay, but young gentleman, fair and ſoftly, you ſhould pay ſome reſpect to your father in this matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Reſpect, maſter Hawthorn! I tell you he ſhall marry her, or I'll diſinherit him! there's once. Look you, Tom, not to make any more words of the matter, I have brought the lady here with me, and I'll ſee you contracted before we part, or you ſhall delve and plant cucumbers as long as you live.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Have you brought the lady here, ſir!— I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
Why ſorry? what then you won't marry her? we'll ſee that! Pray, maſter Hawthorn, conduct the fair one in.—Ay, ſir, you may fret, and dance
about, trot at the rate of fifteen miles an hour, if you pleaſe, but marry, whip me, I'm reſolved.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Here is the lady, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Come, in madam, but turn your face from him—he would not marry you becauſe he had not ſeen you: but I'll let him know my choice ſhall be his, and he ſhall conſent to marry you before he ſees you, or not an acre of eſtate—Pray, ſir, walk this way.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot help thinking your conduct a little extraordinary; but, ſince you urge me ſo cloſely, I muſt tell you my affections are engaged.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: How, Tom, how!

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: I was determined, ſir, to have got the better of my inclination, and never have done a thing which I knew would be diſagreeable to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And pray, ſir, who are your affections engaged to? let me know that.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: To a perſon, ſir, whoſe rank and fortune may be no recommendation to her; but whoſe charms and accompliſhments entitle her to a monarch. I am ſorry, ſir, it's impoſſible for me to comply with your commands, and I hope you will not be offended if I quit your preſence.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Not I, not in the leaſt; go about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Sir, I obey.

div.stage: Roſetta advances, Young Meadows turns round and ſees her.

sp.speaker: 'Roſ.
sp.l: When we ſee a lover languiſh,
'And his truth and honour prove,
'Ah! how ſweet to heal his anguiſh,
'And repay him love for love!'

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, Tom, will you go away from me now?

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Perhaps, S • r William, your ſon does not like the lady; and if ſo, pray don't put a force upon his inclination.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: You need not have taken this method, ſir, to let me ſee you are acquainted with my folly, whatever my inclinations are.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, but Tom, ſuppoſe I give my conſent to your marrying this young woman?

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Your conſent, ſir!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p:
Come, Sir William, we have carried the jeſt fa •
enough; I ſee your ſon is in a kind of embarraſſment, and I don't wonder at it; but this letter, which I received from him a few days before I left my father's houſe, will, I apprehend, expound the riddle. He cannot be ſurprized that I ran away from a gentleman who expreſſed ſo much diſlike to me; and what has happened ſince chance has brought as together in maſquerade, there is no occaſion for me to inform him of.

sp.speaker: 'Y. Meadows.'
sp.p: What is all this? Pray don't make a jeſt of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: May I never do an ill turn, Tom, if it is not truth; this is my friend's daughter.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: S • r!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Even ſ • ; 'tis very true indeed. In ſhort, you have not been a more whimſical gentleman than I have a gentlewoman; but you ſee we are deſigned for one another, 'tis plain.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: I know not, madam, what I either hear or ſee; a thouſand things are crowding on my imagination; while, like one juſt awakened from a dream, I doubt which is reality, which deluſion.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well then, Tom, come into the air a bit, and recover yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Nay, dear ſir, have a little patience;— do you give her to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Give her to you! ay, that I do, and my bleſſing into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
Y. Mead.
sp.l: All I wiſh, in her obtaining,
Fortune can no more impart;

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Let my eyes, my thoughts explaining,
Speak the feelings of my heart.

sp.speaker: Y. Mead.
sp.l: Joy and pleaſure never ceaſing,

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Love with length of years encreaſing.

sp.speaker: Together.
sp.l: Thus my heart and hand ſurrender,
Here my faith and troth I plight;
Conſtant ſtill, and kind, and tender,
May our flames burn ever bright.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Give you joy, ſir; and your fair lady— And, under favour, I'll ſalute you too, if there's no fear of jealouſy.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: And may I believe this?—Pr'ythee tell me, dear Roſetta.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Step into the houſe, and I'll tell you every thing —I muſt intreat the good offices of Sir William and Mr. Hawthorn, immediately; for I am in the utmoſt uneaſineſs about my poor friend Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I don't know, but 'I have reaſon to fear I left her juſt now in very diſagreeable circumſtances; however,' I hope, if there's any miſchief fallen out between her father and her lover—

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: The muſic-maſter! I thought ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What, is there a lover in the caſe? May I never do an ill turn, but I am glad, ſo I am; for we'll make a double wedding; and, by way of celebrating it, take a trip to London, to ſhew the brides ſome of the pleaſures of the town. And, maſter Hawthorn, you ſhall be of the party—Come, children, go before us.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir William; I'll go into the houſe with you, and to church to ſee the young folks married; but as to London, I beg to be excuſed.

div.head: AIR.
div.l: If ever I'm catch'd in thoſe regions of ſmoke,
That ſe • t of confuſion and noiſe,
May I ne'er know the ſweets of a ſlumber unbroke,
Nor the pleaſure the country enjoys;
Nay more, let them take me, to puniſh my ſin,
Where, gaping the Cockneys they fleece,
Clap me up with their monſters, cry, Maſters walk in,
And ſhew me for two-pence a piece.

div.stage: Enter Juſtice Woodcock, Mrs. Deborah Woodcock, Lucinda, Euſtace, Hodge.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Why, brother, do you think I can't hear, or ſee, or make uſe of my ſenſes? I tell you I left that fellow locked up in her cloſet; and, while I have been with you, they have broke open the door, and got him out again.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Well, you hear what they ſay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: I care not what they ſay: it's you encourage them in their impudence—Hark'e, huſſey, will you face me down that I did not lock the fellow up?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Really, aunt, I don't know what you mean; when you talk intelligibly, I'll anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Seriouſly, madam, this is carrying the jeſt a little too far.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: What then, I did not catch you together in her chamber, nor over-heat your deſign of going off tonight, nor find the bundies packed up?—

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Why, aunt, you rave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Brother, as I am a chriſtian woman, ſhe confeſſed the whole affair to me from firſt to laſt; and in this very place was down upon her marrow-bones for half an hour together, to beg I would conceal it from you.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh Lord!

p.hi: What, ſirrah, would you brazen me too? Take that.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: I wiſh you would keep your hands to yourſelf; you ſtrike me, becauſe you have been telling his worſhip ſtories.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Why, ſiſter, you are tipſey!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: I tipſey, brother?—I—that never touch a drop of any thing ſtrong from year's end to year's end; but now and then a little anniſeed-water, when I have got the cholic.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Well, au • , you have been complaining of the ſtomach-ach to-day: and may have taken too powerful a doſe of your cordial.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Come, come, I ſee well enough how it is; this is a lye of her own invention, to make herſelf appear wiſe: but, you ſimpleton, did you not know I muſt find you out?

div.stage: Enter Sir William Meadows, Hawthorn, Roſetta, and Young Meadows.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Bleſs me, ſir! look who is yonder.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Cockſ • ones, Jack! honeſt Jack, are you there?

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Plague on't, this rencounter is unlucky [aſide.] —Sir William, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Your ſervant again, and again, heartily your ſervant; may I never do an ill turn, but I am glad to meet you.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Pray, Sir William, are you acquainted with this perſon?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What, with Jack Euſtace! why he's my kinſman: his mother and I are couſin-germans once removed, and Jack's a very worthy young fellow; may I never do an ill turn if I tell a word of a lye.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Well, but Sir William, let me tell you, you know nothing of the matter; this man is a muſic-maſter; a thrummer of wire, and a ſcraper of cat-gut, and teaches my daughter to ſing.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What, Jack Euſtace a muſic-maſter! no, no, I know him better.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: 'Sdeath,' why ſhould I attempt to carry on this abſurd farce any longer?—What that gentleman tells you, is very true, ſir; I am no muſic-maſter, indeed.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: You are not, you own it then?

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p:
Nay, more, ſir, I am, as this lady has repreſented me, [pointing to Mrs. Deborah] your daughter's lover; whom, with her own conſent, I did intend to have carried off this night; but now that Sir William Meadow •
is here, to tell you who, and what I am; I throw myſelf upon your generoſity, from which I expect greater advantages than I could reap from any impoſition on your unſuſpicious nature.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Well, brother, 'what have you to ſay for yourſelf now?' You have made a precious day's work of it! Had my advice been taken: Oh, I am aſhamed of you: but you are a weak man, and it can't be help'd; however, you ſhould let wiſer heads direct you.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Dear papa, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, do, ſir, forgive her; my couſin Jack will make her a good huſband, I'll anſwer for it.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Stand out of the way, and let me ſpeak two or three words to his worſhip.—Come, my dear ſir, though you refuſe all the world, I am ſure you can deny me nothing: love is a venial fault—you know what I mean.—Be reconciled to your daughter, I conjure you by the memory of our paſt affections—What, not a word!

lg.l: Go, naughty man, I can't abide you;
Are then your vows ſo ſoon forgot?
Ah! now I ſee, if I had try'd you,
What would have been my hopeful lot.
But here I charge you—Make them happy;
Bleſs the fond pair, and crown their bliſs:
Come, be a dear good-natur'd pappy,
And I'll reward you with a kiſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Come, turn out of the houſe, and be thankful my brother does not hang you, for he could do it, he's a juſtice of peace;—turn out of the houſe, I ſay:—

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Who gave you authority to turn him out of the houſe?—he ſhall ſtay where he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: He ſhan't marry my niece.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Shan't • e? 'but I'll ſhew you the difference now,' I ſay he ſhall marry her, and what will you do about it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: And you will give him your eſtate too, will you?

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, I will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Why, I'm ſure he's a vagabond.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: I like him the better, I would have him a vagabond.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: Brother, brother!

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Come, come, madam, all's very well; and I ſee my neighbour is what I always thought him, a man of ſenſe and prudence.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: May I never do an ill turn, but I ſay ſo too.

sp.speaker: J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Here, young fellow, take my daughter, and heaven bleſs you both together;—but h • rk'e,— no money till I die; obſerve that.

sp.speaker: Euſt.
sp.p: Sir, in giving me your daughter, you beſtow upon me, more than the whole world would be without her.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Dear Lucinda, if words could convey the tranſports of my heart upon this occaſion—

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Words are the tools of hypocrites, the pretenders to friendſhip: only let us reſolve to preſerve our eſteem for each other.

sp.speaker: Y. Meadows.
sp.p: Dear Jack, I little thought we ſhould ever meet in ſuch odd circumſtances—but here has been the ſtrangeſt buſineſs between this lady and me—

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p: What then, Mrs. Roſetta, are you turned falſe-hearted after all; will you marry Thomas the gardener? and did I forſake Madge for this?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p:
Oh lord! Hodge, I beg your pardon; I proteſt
I forgot; but I muſt reconcile you and M • dge, I think, and give you a wedding-dinner to make you amends.
N—ah.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
J. Woodcock.
sp.p: Why, here's my hand, and we will enjoy ourſelves; Heaven bleſs you b • th, children, I ſay— Siſter Deborah, you are a fool.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Deb.
sp.p: You are a fool, brother; and mark my words—But I'll give myſelf no more trouble about you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hawth.
sp.p: Fiddlers, ſtrike up.

lg.l: Hence with cares, complaints, and frowning,
Welcome jollity and joy;
Ev'ry grief in pleaſure drowning,
Mirth this happy night employ:
Let's to friendſhip do our duty,
Laugh and ſing ſome good old ſtrain;
Drink a health to love and beauty—
May they long in triumph reign.

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: Let's to friendſhip, &c.

div.head: NEW SONG, ſet by SACCHINI, introduced by Mrs. BILLINGTON, at Covent-Garden, inſtead of that at page 38.
div.l: Ah! the rural ſcene no more
Shall hear the tale of love;
The golden reign of truth is o'er,
And daemons haunt the grove.

div.head: BOOKS printed by MATHEW CAREY, And for ſale, at his ſtore, No. 118, Market-ſtreet, Philadelphia:
div.p: 1. AMERICAN MUSEUM from its commencement in January, 1787, to its termination in December, 1792, in twelve volumes, price, neatly bound and lettered, nineteen dollars and one fifth.
The opinion of the Preſident of the United States reſpecting this work, is as follows:

"I believe the American Muſeum has met with extenſive▪ I may ſay with univerſal approbation from competent judges; for I am of opinion, that the work is not only eminently calculated to diſſeminate political, agricultural, philoſophical, and other information— but that it has been uniformly conducted with taſte, attention and propriety. If to theſe important objects be ſuperadded the more immediate deſign, of reſcuing public documents from oblivion—I will venture to pronounce, as my ſentiment, That a more uſeful literary plan has never been undertaken in America, or one more deſerving of public encouragement.

2. A complete Atlas for the preſent war; containing,
1. Map of the United Provinces,
2. Map of the French, Dutch, and Auſtrian Netherlands.
3. Map of France divided into departments.
4. Map of Spain and Portugal.
5. Map of Germany and Switzerland.
6. Map of Italy.
7. Chart of the Weſt-Indies.
(Price Two Dollars.)

3. A ſhort Account of ALGIERS, containing a deſcription of that country, of the manners and cuſtoms of the inhabitants, and of their ſeveral wars againſt Spain, France, England, Holland, Venice, and other powers of Europe; from the uſurpation of Barbaroſſa and the invaſion of the emperor Charles V. to the preſent time; with a conciſe view of the Origin of the Rupture between Algiers and the United States; with a map of Algiers, Fez, Morocco, Tunis, and Tripoli.—1ſ10 ½.
4. A ſhort Account of the Malignant Fever, lately prevalent in Philadelphia. To which are added an Account of the Plague in London and at Marſeilles.—Price Half a Dollar.
5. The Romp, a Muſical Entertainment.—Price 1ſ.
6. The Farmer, a comic opera.—Price 1ſ.
7. Don Juan, a pantomimical ballet.—Price 1ſ.
8. No Song no Supper.—Price 1ſ.
9. Wild Oats.—Price 1ſ6.
10. The Miſſes Magazine.—Price, bound in two volumes, 11ſ3.
11. A brief examination of the obſervations of lord Sheffield, on the commerce of the United States.—Price 5-8ths of a dollar.

12. The Conſtitution of the ſeveral States, with the Federal Conſtitution and the Amendments thereto. N. B. This edition contains the Conſtitution of Vermont; not in any former one.— Price 5-8ths of a dollar.
13. Mr Fingal, an epic poem. By John Trumbull, Eſq. A new edition in 12mo.—Price 3-8ths of a dollar bound.
14. American Jeſt Book, in two parts, with two very neat engravings.—Price bound, 3- • ths of a dollar.
15. The HOLY BIBLE, tranſlated from the Latin Vulgate. —Price in plain binding, 6 dollars—in calf, lettered, 50ſ2.
16. The Garden of the • ul. Price, on fine paper, and bound in calf and lettered, three •• arters of a dollar—on common paper, plain binding, half a dollar▪
17. The devout Chriſtian's Vade Mecum, being a ſummary of ſelect and neceſſary devotions. Price a quarter of a dollar.
18. Think Well O' • t, or Reflections for every day in the Month. By Bi • hop Chancellor. Price a quarter of a dollar.
19. Chriſtian Economy, tranſlated from a Greek manuſcript found in the iſland of Patmo • , where Saint John wrote the Apocalypſe. Price a fifth of a dollar.
20. Hiſtory of Charles Grandiſon, abridged. Price a ſixth of a dollar.
21. Poems by Col. Humphreys. Price a third of a dollar.
22. Select Poems. Price a ſixth of a dollar.
23. Blair's Lectures on Rhetoric and Belles Lettres, 2 vols. 8vo. 25ſ.
24. Burke's Reflections on the French Revolution.—7ſ6.
25. Buchan's Domeſtic Medicine. 15ſ.
26. Letters from an American Farmer, deſcribing certain provincial ſituations, manners and cuſtoms, 5ſ7 ½.
27. Smith's Letters to Married Women, on nurſing and the management of Children. 4ſ8.
28. Charms of Melody, a choice collection of valuable Songs. 1ſ10 ½.
29. Duncan's Elements of Logic. 5ſ7 ½.
30. Beauties of Fielding. 3ſ.
31. Beautie's of Blair. 3ſ9.
32. The Ladies' Library. 6ſ6.

33. Smith's Hiſtory of New-York, from its firſt ſettlement to the year 1782. To which is annexed, a deſcription of the country, with a ſhort account of the inhabitants, their religious and political ſtate, and the conſtitution of the Courts of Juſtice. Price a dollar and a quarter.
34. Elements of Moral Science. By James Beattie, L. L. D. Price three fourths of a dollar.
35. Sermons, by Hugh Blair, D. D. Price two dollars.
THE SUSPICIOUS HUSBAND, A COMEDY BY THE RIGHT REVEREND DR. BENJAMIN HOADLY.
PHILADELPHIA: PRINTED BY WILLIAM SPOTSWOOD M DCC XCI.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.
div.p: SCENE, LONDON.

lg.l: WHILE other culprits brave it to the laſt;
Nor beg for mercy till the judgment's paſt:
Poets alone, as conſcious of their crimes,
Open their trials with imploring rhymes.
Thus cramm'd with flattery and low ſubmiſſion,
Each trite dull prologue is the bard's petition.
A ſtale device to calm the critic's fury,
And bribe at once the judges and the jury.
But what avail ſuch poor repeated arts?
The whimp'ring ſcribbler ne'er can touch your hearts:
Nor ought an ill-tim'd pity to take place—
Faſt as they riſe, deſtroy th' increaſing race:
The vermin elſe will run the nation o'er—
By ſaving one, you breed a million more.
Tho' diſappointed authors rail and rage,
At fancy'd parties, and a ſenſeleſs age,
Yet ſtill has juſtice triumph'd on the ſtage.
Thus ſpeaks and thinks the author of to-day,
And ſaying this, has little more to ſay.
He aſks no friend his partial zeal to ſhow,
Nor fears the groundleſs cenſures of a foe;
He knows no friendſhip can protect the fool,
Nor will an audience be a party's tool.
'Tis inconſiſtent with a free-born ſpirit,
To ſide with folly, or to injure merit.
By your deciſion he muſt fall or ſtand,
Nor, tho' he feels the laſh, will blame the hand.
THO' the young ſmarts, I ſee, begin to ſneer,
And the old ſinners caſt a wicked leer:
Be not alarm'd, ye fair—you've nought to fear.
No wanton hint, no looſe ambiguous ſenſe,
Shall flatter vicious taſte at your expence,
Leaving for once theſe ſhameleſs arts in vogue:
We give a Fable for the Epilogue.
AN aſs there was, our author bid me ſay,
Who needs muſt write—he did—and wrote a play.
The parts were caſt to various beaſts and fowl:
Their ſtage a barn;—the manager an owl!
The houſe was cramm'd at ſix, with friends and foes;
Rakes, wits, and critics, citizens and beaux.
Theſe characters appear'd in different ſhapes
Of tigers, foxes, horſes, bulls and apes;
With others too, of lower rank and ſtation:—
A perfect abſtract of the brute creation!
Each, as he felt, mark'd out the author's faults,
And thus the connoiſſeurs expreſs'd their thoughts.
The critic curs firſt ſnarl'd—the rules are broke!
Time, place, and action ſacrific'd to joke!
The goats cry'd out, 'twas formal, dull, and chaſte—
Not writ for beaſts of gallantry and taſte!
The horned-cattle were in piteous taking,
At fornification, rapes and cuckold making!
The tigers ſwore, he wanted fire and paſſion.
The apes condemn'd—becauſe it was the faſhion!
The generous ſteeds allow'd him proper merit:
Here mark'd his faults, and there approv'd his ſpirit.
While brother-bards bray'd forth with uſual ſpleen,
And, as they heard, exploded every ſcene.
When reynard's thoughts were aſk • d, the ſhrugging ſage,
Fam'd for hypocriſy, and worn with age,
Condemn'd the ſhameleſs licence of the ſtage!
At which the monkey ſkipp'd from box to box,
And whiſper'd round the judgment of the fox:
Abus'd the moderns, talk'd of Rome and Greece!
Bilk'd every box-keeper; and damn'd the piece.
Now every fable has a moral to it—
Be churchman, ſtateſman, any thing—but poet.
In law, or phyſic, quack in what you will;
Cant, and grimace conceal the want of ſkill!
Secure in theſe, his gravity may paſs—
But here no artifice can hide the aſs.

div.head: SCENE I. Ranger's Chambers in the Temple.
div.p: ONCE more I am got ſafe to the Temple—let me reflect a little—I have ſat up all night. I have my head full of bad wine, and the noiſe of oaths, dice, and the damned tingling of tavern bells; my ſpirits jaded, and my eyes ſunk into my head: and all this for the converſation of a company of fellows I deſpiſe. Their wit lies only in obſcenity, their mirth in noiſe, and their delight in a box and dice. Honeſt Ranger take my word for it, thou art a mighty ſilly fellow.
div.stage: Enter Servant, with a wig dreſs'd.
div.p: Where have you been, raſcal? If I had not had the key in my pocket, I muſt have waited at the door in this dainty dreſs.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I was only below combing out your honor's wig.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: [Pulling off his wig.] Well, give me my cap —why, how like a raking dog do you look, compared to that ſpruce, ſober gentleman—Go, you battered devil and be made fit to be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Cod, my maſter's very merry this morning,

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: And now for the law. Reads.

lg.l: Tell me no more I am deceiv'd,
That Chloe's falſe and common.
By Heav'n, I all along believ'd
She was a very woman.
As ſuch I lik'd, as ſuch careſs'd;
She ſtill was conſtant when poſſeſt:
She could do more for no man.

sp.p:
Honeſt Congreve was a man after my own heart.
Enter Servant. Have you been for the money this morning, as I ordered you?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, ſir, you bad me go before you was up— I did not know your honor meant before you went to to bed.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: None of your jokes, I pray, but to buſineſs— go to the coffee-houſe, and enquire if there has been any letter or meſſage left for me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I ſhall, ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rang.

l.hi: You think ſhe's falſe, I'm ſure ſhe's kind,
I take her body, you her mind;

sp.p: Oh, that I had ſuch a ſoft, deceitful fair to lull my ſenſes to their deſired ſleep— [Knocking at the door.] Come in.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Oh, maſter Simon, is it you? How long have you been in town?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Juſt come, ſir, and but for a little time neither; and yet I have as many meſſages as if we were to ſtay the whole year round. Here they are all of them. [Pulls out a number of cards.] And among them one for your honor.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: [Reads] Clarinda's Compliments to her Couſin Ranger, and ſhould be glad to ſee him for ever ſo little a time that can be ſpared from the more weighty buſineſs of the law— Ha! ha! ha! the ſame merry girl I ever knew her.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: My lady is never ſad, ſir, Knocking at the door.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Pry'thee, Simon, open the door. Enter Millener. Well, child—and who are you?

sp.speaker: Mille.
sp.p: Sir my miſtreſs gives her ſervice to you, and has ſent you home the linen you beſpoke.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Well Simon, my ſervice to your lady, and let her know I will moſt certainly wait upon her—I am a little buſy, Simon—and ſo—

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Ah, you're a wag, Maſter Ranger, you're a wag—but mum for that! Exit.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I ſwear my dear, you have the prettieſt pair of eyes—the lovelieſt pouting lips—I never ſaw you before.

sp.speaker: Mille.
sp.p: No, ſir, I was always in the ſhop.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Was you ſo? Well, and what does your miſtreſs ſay?—The Devil fetch me, child, you looked ſo prettily, that I could not mind one word you ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mille.
sp.p: Lard, ſir, you are ſuch another gentleman! Why, ſhe ſays ſhe is ſorry ſhe could not ſend them ſooner. Shall I lay them down?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: No, child. Give'em me! dear little ſmiling angel— Catches and kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Mille.
sp.p: I beg, ſir, you would be civil.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Civil! Egad, I think I am very civil.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Damn your impertinence—Oh, Mr. Ballamy, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Mille.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay to my miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Bid her make half a dozen more; but be ſure you bring them home yourſelf. [Exit Millener] Pſhah! pox! Mr. Bellamy, how ſhould you like to be ſerved ſo yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: How can you, Ranger, for a minute's pleaſure, give an innocent girl the pain of heart I am confident ſhe felt?—There was a modeſt bluſh upon her cheek convinces me ſhe was honeſt.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: May be ſo. I was reſolved to try, however.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Fy, Ranger,—will you never think?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
Yes, but I can't be always thinking. The law is a damnable dry ſtudy, Mr. Bellamy, and without ſomething now and then to amuſe, and relax, it would be too much for my brain, I promiſe ye—but I am a mighty ſober fellow grown—Here have I been
at it theſe three hours—but the wenches will never let me alone—

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Three hours! Why, do you uſually ſtudy in ſuch ſhoes and ſtockings?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Rat your inquiſitive Eyes. Ex pede Herculem. Egad, you have me! The truth is I am but this moment returned from the tavern. What, Frankly here too!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My boy Ranger, I am heartily glad to ſee you. Bellamy, let me embrace you. You are the perſon I want. I have been at your lodgings, and was directed hither.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: It is to him then I am obliged for this viſit: but with all my heart—he is the only man, to whom I don't care how much I am obliged.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Your very humble ſervant, ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You know Ranger, I want no inducement to be with you. But—you look ſadly—what—no mercileſs jade has—has ſhe?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: No, no, ſound as a roach my lad. I only got a little too much liquor laſt night, which I have not ſlept off yet.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Thus, Frankly, it is every day. All the morning his head aches, at noon he begins to clear up, towards evening he is good company, and all night he is carefully providing for the ſame courſe the next day.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why, I muſt own, my ghoſtly father, I did relapſe a little laſtnight, juſt to furniſh out a decent confeſſion for the day.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And he is now doing penance for it. Were you his confeſſor indeed, you could not well deſire more.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Charles, he ſets up for a confeſſor with the worſt grace in the world. Here he has been reproving me for being but decently civil to my millener. Plague! becauſe the coldneſs of his conſtitution makes him inſenſible of a fine woman's charms, every body elſe muſt be ſo too.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I am no leſs ſenſible of their charms than you are; tho' I cannot kiſs every woman I meet, or fall in love, as you call it, with every face which has the bloom of youth upon it. I would only have you a little more frugal of your pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My dear friend, this is very pretty talking. But let me tell you, it is in the power of the very firſt glance from a fine woman utterly to diſconcert all your philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: It muſt be from a fine woman then: and not ſuch as are generally reputed ſo—and it muſt be a thorough acquaintance with her too, that will ever make an impreſſion on my heart.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Would I could ſee it once! for when a man has been all his life hoarding up a ſtock, without allowing himſelf common neceſſaries, it tickles me to the ſoul to ſee him lay it all out upon a wrong bottom, and become a bankrupt at laſt.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Well, I don't care how ſoon you ſee it. For the minute I find a woman capable of friendſhip, love, and tenderneſs, with good ſenſe enough to be always eaſy, and good nature enough to like me, I will immediately put it to the trial, which of us ſhall have the greateſt ſhare of happineſs from the ſex, you or I.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: By marrying her, I ſuppoſe! Capable of friendſhip, love, and tenderneſs, ha, ha, ha! That a man of your ſenſe ſhould talk ſo. If ſhe be capable of love 'tis all I require of my miſtreſs; and as every woman, who is young, is capable of love, I am very reaſonably in love with every young woman I meet.—My Lord Coke, in a caſe I read this very morning, ſpeaks my very ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: My Lord Coke!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord Coke! What he ſays of one woman, I ſay of the whole ſex. I take their bodies, you their minds; which has the better bargain?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There is no arguing with ſo great a lawyer. Suppoſe therefore we adjourn the debate to ſome other time. I have ſome ſerious buſineſs with Mr. Bellamy, and you want ſleep I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Sleep! mere loſs of time, and hindrance of buſineſs—We men of ſpirit, ſir, are above it.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Whither ſhall we go?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Into the Park. My chariot is at the door.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Then if my ſervant calls, you'll ſend him after us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
I will. [Looking on the card.] Clarinda's
compliments—a pox of this head of mine! Never once to aſk where ſhe was to be found. It's plain ſhe is not one of us, or • ſhould not have been ſo remiſs in my inquiries.—No matter—I ſhall meet her in my walks.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: There is no letter nor meſſage, ſir.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Then my things, to dreſs Exeunt

div.head: SCENE II. A CHAMBER.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Strictland and Jacintha, meeting.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Good-morrow my dear Jacintha.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Good-morrow to you, madam. I have brought my work, and intend to ſit with you this morning. I hope you have got the better of your fatigue. Where is Clarinda? I ſhould be glad if ſhe would come and work with us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: She work! ſhe is too fine a lady to do any thing. She is not ſtirring yet—we muſt let her have her reſt. People of her waſte of ſpirits require more time to recruit again.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: It is pity ſhe ſhould be ever tired with what is ſo agreeable to every body elſe. I am prodigiouſly pleaſed with her company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: And when you are better acquainted, you will be ſtill more pleaſed with her. You muſt rally her upon her partner at Bath: for, I fancy, part of her reſt has been diſturbed on his account.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Was he really a pretty fellow?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: That I can't tell. I did not dance myſelf, and ſo did not much mind him. You muſt have the whole ſtory from herſelf.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Oh! I warrant ye, I get it all out. None are ſo proper to make diſcoveries in love as thoſe who are in the ſecret themſelves.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p:
Madam, Mr. Strictland is enquiring for you.
Here has been Mr. Buckle with a letter from his maſter, which has made him very angry.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Mr. Bellamy, ſaid indeed he would try him once more, but I fear it will prove in vain. Tell your maſter I am here. [Exit Lucetta] What ſignifies fortune, when it only makes us ſlaves to other people?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Do not be uneaſy, my Jacintha You ſhall always find a friend in me: but as for Mr. Strictland, I know not what ill temper hangs about him lately. Nothing ſatisfies him. You ſaw how he received us when we came off our journey; tho' Clarinda was ſo good company. He was barely civil to her, and downright rude to me.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I cannot help ſaying I did obſerve it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I ſaw you did. Huſh! he's here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Oh, your ſervant, madam! here I have received a letter from Mr Bellamy, wherein he deſires I would once more hear what he has to ſay—You know my ſentiments — Nay, ſo does he.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake conſider, ſir. This is no new affair, no ſudden ſtart of paſſion—We have known each other long. My father valued and loved him; and I am ſure were he alive, I ſhould have his conſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Don't tell me. Your father would not have you marry againſt his will; neither will I, againſt mine; I am your father now.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: And you take a fatherly care of me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I wiſh I had never had any thing to do with you.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: You may eaſily get rid of the trouble.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: By liſtening, I ſuppoſe, to the young gentleman's propoſals.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Which are very reaſonable, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p:
Oh, very modeſt ones, truly; and a very modeſt gentleman it is that propoſes them! a fool, to expect a lady of thirty thouſand pounds fortune ſhould, by the care and prudence of her guardian, be thrown away upon a young fellow not worth three hundred a year. He thinks being in love is an excuſe
for all this; but I am not in love. What does he think will excuſe me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Well, but Mr. Strictland, I think the gentleman ſhould be heard.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Well, well! Seven o'clock is the time if the man has the good fortune, ſince I ſaw him laſt, to perſuade ſomebody or other to give him a better eſtate, I give him my conſent not elſe. His ſervant waits below. You may tell him, I ſhall be at home. [Exit Jacin.] But where is your friend, your other half, all this while? I thought you could not have breath'd a minute without your Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Why, the truth is, I was going to ſee what makes her keep her chamber ſo long.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Look ye Mrs. Strictland, you have been aſking me for money this morning. In plain terms, not one ſhilling ſhall paſs through theſe fingers, till you have cleared my houſe of this Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: How can her innocent gaiety have offended you? She is a woman of honor, and has as many good qualities—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: As women of honor generally have. I know it and therefore am uneaſy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: But, ſir,—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: But madam,—Clarinda, nor e'er a rake of faſhion in England, ſhall live in my family to debauch it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe treated me with ſo much civility in the country, that I thought I could not do leſs than invite her to ſpend as much time with me in town, as her engagements would permit. I little imagined you could have been diſpleaſed at my having ſo agreeable a companion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: There was a time when I was company enough for leiſure hours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: There was a time when every word of mine was ſure of meeting with a ſmile: but thoſe happy days, I know not why, have long been over.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I cannot bear a rival, even of your own ſex. I hate the very name of female friends. No two of you can ever be an hour by yourſelves, but one or both are the worſe for it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Strictland.—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: This I know,—and will not ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: It grieves me, ſir, to ſee you ſo much in earneſt: but to convince you how willing I am to make you eaſy in every thing, it ſhall be my requeſt to her to remove immediately.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict
sp.p: Do it then—hark ye?—your requeſt, why your's? it's mine.—My command—tell her ſo— I will be maſter in my own family, and I care not who knows it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: You fright me, ſir —but it ſhall be as you pleaſe. [In tears.] Goes out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Ha! have I not gone too far? I am not ma • er of myſelf—Mrs. Strictland.— [ſhe returns.] Underſtand me right. I do not mean by what I have ſaid, that I ſuſpect your innocence: but by cruſhing this growing friendſhip all at once, I may prevent a train of miſchief which you do not foreſee. I was perhaps too harſh, therefore do it in your own way. But let me ſee the houſe fairly rid of her. Exit. Mr. Strictland.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: His earneſtneſs in this affair amazes me. I am ſorry I made this viſit to Clarinda— and yet I'll anſwer for her honor—what can I ſay to her? Neceſſity muſt plead in my excuſe—for at all events, Mr. Strictland muſt be obeyed.

div.head: SCENE III. St. JAMES'S PARK.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Now, Bellamy, I may unfold the ſecret of my heart to you with greater freedom; for though Ranger has honor, I am not in a humour to be laughed at. I muſt have one, that will bear with my impertinence, ſooth me into hope, and like a friend indeed, with tenderneſs adviſe me.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I thought you appeared more grave than uſual.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Oh! Bellamy, my ſoul is ſo full of joy, of
pain, hope, deſpair and extaſy, that no word but love is capable of expreſſing what I feel.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Is love the ſecret Ranger is not fit to hear? In my mind, he wou'd prove the more able counſellor. And is all the gay indifference of my friend at laſt reduced to love?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Even ſo—Never was prude more • eſolute in chaſtity and ill-nature, than I was fixed in indifference: but love has rais'd me from that inactive ſtate above the being of a man.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Faith, Charles, I begin to think it has—but pray bring this rapture into order a little, and tell me regularly, how, where, and when?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: If I was not moſt unreaſonably in love, thoſe horrid queſtions would ſtop my mouth at once. But as I am arm'd againſt reaſon—I anſwer—at Bath—on Tueſday, ſhe danced and caught me.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Danced?—and was that all? But who is ſhe? What is her name? her fortune? where does ſhe live?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Hold! hold! not ſo many hard queſtions. Have a little mercy. I know but little of her, that • s certain. But all I do know you ſhall have. That evening was the firſt of her appearing at Bath. The moment I ſaw her I reſolved to aſk the favour of her hand. But the eaſy freedom with which ſhe gave it, and her unaffected good-humour during the whole night, gain • d ſuch a power over my heart, as none of her ſex could ever boaſt before. I waited on her home, and the next morning, when I went to make the uſual compliments, the bird was flown. She had ſet out for London two hours before; and in a chariot and ſix—you rogue.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: But was it her own, Charles?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That I don't know; but it looks better than being drag'd to own in the ſtage. That day and the next I ſpent in enquiries. I waited on the ladies who came with her. They knew nothing of her. So, without learning either her name or fortune, I e'en call'd for my boots, and rode poſt after her.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: And how do you find yourſelf after your journey?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Why, as yet, I own, I am but upon a cold
ſcent. But a woman of her ſprightlineſs and gentility cannot but frequent all public places; and when once ſhe is found, the pleaſure of the chaſe will over-pay the pains of rouſing her. Oh! Bellamy, there was ſomething peculiarly charming in her, that ſeemed to claim my farther acquaintance: and if in the other more familiar parts of life ſhe ſhines with that ſuperior luſtre, and at laſt I win her to my arms, how ſhall I bleſs my reſolution in purſuing her!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: But if, at laſt ſhe ſhould prove unworthy—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I would endeavour to forget her.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Promiſe me that, Charles, [Takes his hand.] and I allow—but we are interrupted.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Whom have we here? my old friend Frankly? Thou art grown a meer antique ſince I ſaw thee: how haſt thou done theſe five hundred years?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Even as you ſee me; well, and at your ſervice, ever.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Ha! who's that?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A friend of mine. Mr. Bellamy, this is Jacky Meggot, ſir, as honeſt a fellow as any in life.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Pho! prithee! pox! Charles—Don't be ſilly—Sir, I am your humble—Any one who is a friend of my Frankly's I am proud of embracing.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall endeavour to deſerve your civility.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Oh! ſir,—Well! Charles, what?—dumb? Come, come; you may talk tho' you have nothing to ſay, as I do—Let us hear, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, for this laſt week, Jack, I have been at Bath?

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Bath! the moſt ridiculous place in life! —amongſt tradeſmens wives that hate their huſbands, and people of quality that had rather go to the devil than ſtay at home. People of no taſte—no go • ſt— and for divertimenti; if it were not for the puppet-ſhow, la vertu would be dead amongſt them.—But the news, Charles?—the ladies,—I fear your time hung heavy on your hands, by the ſmall ſlay you made there.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Faith and ſo it did Jack. The ladies are grown ſuch idiots in love—the cards have ſo debauch'd
their five ſenſes, that Love, almighty Love himſelf, is utterly neglected.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: It is the ſtrangeſt thing in life, but it is juſt ſo with us abroad. Faith! Charles! to tell you a ſecret, which I don't care, if all the world knows, I am almoſt ſurfeited with the ſervices of the ladies; ſhe modeſt ones I mean. The vaſt variety of duties they expect—a • dreſſing up to the faſhion, loſing faſhionably, keeping f • ſhionable hours, drinking faſhionable liquors, and fifty other ſuch irregular niceties, ſo ruin a man's pocket and conſtitution, that foregad! he muſt have the eſtate of a duke, and the ſtrength of a gondolier, who would liſt himſelf into their ſervi • e!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A free confeſſion truly, Jack, for one of your coat.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: The ladies are oblig'd to you.

div.stage: Enter Buckle, with a l • tter to Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Oh lard! Charles! I have had the greateſt misfortune in life, ſince I ſaw you—poor Otho! that I brought from Rome with me, is dead.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well! well! get you another, and all will be well again.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p:
No! the rogue broke me ſo much china, and gnaw'd my Spaniſh
• ea • her ſhoes ſo filthily, that when he was dead, I beg • n not to endure him.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Exactly at ſeven! run back, and aſſure him I will not fa • l. [Exit Buckle.] Dead! pray, who was the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p:
This gentleman was my monkey, ſir,— an odd ſort of a fe •• ow that uſed to divert me,—and pleaſed every body ſo at Rome, that he always made o •
• n our converſazioni. But Mr. Bellamy, I ſaw a ſervant, I hope no engagement. For you two poſitively ſhall dine with me. I have the fineſt macaroni in life. Oblige me ſo far.

sp.speaker: Bella,
sp.p: Sir,— your ſervant! what ſay you, Frankly?

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Pho! pox! Charles! you ſhall go. My aunts think you begin to neglect them; and old maids, you know, are the moſt jealous creatures in life.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ranger ſwears they can't be maids, they are ſo good natur • d! Well! I agree, on condition I may eat what I pleaſe, and go away juſt when I will.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Ay! ay! you ſhall do juſt what you will. But how ſhall we do? my poſt-chaiſe won't carry us all.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: My chariot is here; and I will conduct Mr. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Mr. Meggot,—I beg pardon, I can't poſſibly dine out of town! I have an engagement early in the evening.—

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Out of town! no, my dear! I live juſt by. I ſee one of the Dilettanti, I would not miſs ſpeaking to for the univerſe. And ſo I expect you at three. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! and ſo you thought you had at leaſt fifty miles to go poſt for a ſpoonful of macaroni.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe then he is juſt come out of the country.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nor that neither. I would venture a wager, from his own houſe hither; or to an auction or two of old dirty pictures, is the utmoſt of his travels to-day: or he may have been in purſuit, perhaps, of a new cargo of Venetian tooth-picks.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: A ſpecial acquaintance I have made to-day.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: For all this, Bellamy, he has a heart worthy your friendſhip. He ſpends his eſtate freely, and you cannot oblige him more, than by ſhowing him how he can be of ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Now you ſay ſomething. It is the heart, Frankly, I value in a man.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Right!—and there is a heart even in a woman's breaſt that is worth the purchaſe, or my judgment has deceived me. Dear Bellamy, I know your concern for me. See her firſt, and then blame me, if you can.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: So far from blaming you, Charles, that if my endeavours can be ſerviceable, I will beat the buſhes with you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That I am afraid will not do. For you know leſs of her than I. But if in your walks you meet a finer woman than ordinary, let her not eſcape till I have ſeen her.—Whereſoe'er ſhe is, ſhe cannot long lie hid. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Clarinda, Jacintha and Mrs. Strictland.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: AY! ay! we both ſtand condemn'd out of our own mouths.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why I cannot but own—I never had a thought of any man that troubled me, but of him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Then I dare ſwear, by this time, you heartily repent your leaving Bath ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Indeed you are miſtaken. I have not had one ſcruple ſince.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Why, what one inducement can he have ever to think of you again?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh! the greateſt of all inducements, curioſity. Let me aſſure you, a woman's ſureſt hold over a man is to keep him in uncertainty. As ſoon as ever you put him out of doubt, you put him out of your power: but when once a woman has awak'd his curioſity, ſhe may lead him a dance of many a troubleſome mile without the leaſt fear of loſing him at laſt.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Now do I heartily wiſh he may have ſpirit enough to follow and uſe you as you deſerve. Such a ſpirit, with but a little knowledge of our ſex, might put that heart of yours into a ſtrange flutter.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I care not how ſoon. I long to meet with ſuch a fellow. Our modern beaux are ſuch jointed babies in love, they have no feeling. They are entirely inſenſible either of pain or pleaſure, but from their own dear perſons: and according as we flatter, or affront their beauty, they admire or forſake ours. They are not worthy even our diſpleaſure; and, in ſhort, abuſing them is but ſo much ill-nature merely thrown away. But the man of ſenſe, who values himſelf upon his high abilities: or the man of wit, who thinks a woman beneath his converſation—to ſee ſuch the ſubjects of our power, the ſlaves of our frowns and ſmiles is glorious indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: No men of ſenſe, or wit either, if they be truly ſo, ever did, or ever can think a woman of merit beneath their wiſdom to converſe with.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Nor will ſuch a woman value herſelf upon making ſuch a lover uneaſy.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Amazing! why, every woman can give eaſe; you cannot be in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I can aſſure you ſhe is, and has put in practice the doctrine ſhe has been teaching.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Impoſſible! who ever heard the name of love mention'd without an idea of torment? But pray let us hear.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Nay, there is nothing to hear that I know of.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: So I ſuſpected, indeed! the novel is not likely to be long, when the lady is ſo well prepared for the denouement.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: The novel, as you call it, is not ſo ſhort as you may imagine. I and my ſpark have been long acquainted. As he was continually with my father, I ſoon perceived that he loved me, and the manner of his expreſſing that love was what pleas'd and won me moſt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well! and how was it? the old bait! Flattery, dear Flattery, I warrant ye?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: No indeed,—I had not the pleaſure of hearing my perſon, wit and beauty painted out with forced praiſes; but I had a more ſenſible delight in perceiving the drift of his whole behaviour was to make every hour of my time paſs-away agreeably.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The ruſtic! what, did he never ſay a handſome thing of your perſon?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: He did, it ſeems what pleas'd her better. He flatter'd her good ſenſe as much as a leſs cunning lover would have done her beauty.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: On my conſcience you are well match'd.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: So well, that if my guardian denies me happineſs, (and this evening he is to paſs his final ſentence) nothing is left but to break my priſon, and fly into my lover's arms for ſafety.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Hey day! O my conſcience, thou art a brave girl. Thou art the very firſt prude that ever had honeſty enough to avow her paſſion for a man.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: And thou art the firſt finiſh'd coquet who ever had any honeſty at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Come, come! you are both too good for either of thoſe characters.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And my dear Mrs. Strictland here, is the firſt young married woman of ſpirit, who has an ill-natur'd fellow for a huſband, and never once thinks of uſing him as he deſerves.—Good heaven, if I had ſuch a huſband—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: You would be juſt as unhappy as I am.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But come now—confeſs—do not you long to be a widow?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Would I were any thing but what I am!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Then go the neareſt way about it. I'd break that ſtout heart of his in leſs than a fortnight. I'd make him know—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Pray be ſilent. You know my reſolution.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I know you have no reſolution.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: You are a mad creature, but I forgive you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
It is all meant kindly, I aſſure you. But ſince you won't be perſuaded to your good; I will think of making you eaſy in your ſubmiſſion as ſoon as ever I can. I dare ſay, I may have the ſame lodging I had laſt year. I can know immediately—I ſee my chair: and ſo ladies both, adieu!
Exit Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Come, Mrs. Strictland, we ſhall but juſt have time to get home before Mr. Bellamy comes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Let us return then to our common priſon. You muſt forgive my ill-nature, Jacintha, if I almoſt wiſh Mr. Strictland may refuſe to join your hand where your heart is given.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Lord! madam, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Self-intereſt only, child! methinks your company in the country would ſoften all my ſorrows, and I could bear them patiently.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Strictland—I am ſo confus'd, and ſo out of breath—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Why, why what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I proteſt you fright me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Oh! I have no time to recover myſelf, I am
ſo frighten'd and ſo pleas'd. In ſhort then, the dear man is here?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Here—lord—where?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I met him this inſtant. I ſaw him at a diſtance, turn'd ſhort; and ran hither directly. Let us go home, I tell you he follows me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Why, had you not better ſtay, and let him ſpeak to you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ay! but—then—he won't know where I live without telling him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Come, the • Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Ah! poor Clarinda!—Allons don • . Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sure that muſt be ſhe! her ſhape and eaſy air cannot be ſo exactly copied by another.—Now, you young rogue, Cupid, guide me directly to her, as you would the ſureſt arrow in your quiver. Exit.

div.head: SCENE II. Changes to the ſtreet before Mr. Strictland's door.
div.stage: Re-enter Clarinda, Jacintha, and Mrs. Strictland.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Lord!—dear Jacintha—for heaven's ſake make haſte. He'll overtake us before we get in.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Overtake us? Why, he is not in ſight.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Is not he? Ha! ſure I have not dropped my twee—I would not have him loſe ſight of me neither.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Here he is—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: In—in— in then.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: [Laughing.] What, without your twee?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Pſhah! I have loſt nothing—In—I'll follow you.
Exeunt into the houſe. Clarinda laſt.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It is impoſſible I ſhould be deceived: my eyes and the quick pulſes at my heart aſſure me it is ſhe. Ha! 'tis ſhe, by heaven! and the door left open too— a fair invitation, by all the rules of Love— Exit.

div.head: SCENE III. Changes to an apartment in Mr. Strictland's houſe.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I hope, madam, you will excuſe the boldneſs of this intruſion, ſince it is owing to your own behaviour that I am forc'd to it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: To my behaviour, ſir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You cannot but remember me at Bath, madam, where I ſo lately had the favour of your hand—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I do remember, ſir; but I little expected any wrong interpretation of my behaviour, from one, who had ſo much the appearance of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What I ſaw of your behaviour was ſo juſt, it would admit of no miſinterpretation. I only fear'd, whatever reaſon you had to conceal your name from me at Bath, you might have the ſame to do it now; and tho' my happineſs was ſo nearly concerned, I rather choſe to venture thus abruptly after you, than be impertinently inquiſitive.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sir, there ſeems to be ſo much civility in your rudeneſs, that I can eaſily forgive it; tho' I don't ſee how your happineſs is at all concerned.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, madam! I believe you are the only lady, who could with the qualifications you are miſtreſs of, be inſenſible of the power they give you over the happineſs of our ſex.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How vain ſhould we women be, if you gentlemen were but wiſe! if you did not all of you ſay the ſame things to every woman, we ſhould certainly be fooliſh enough to believe ſome of you were in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Could you have the leaſt ſenſe of what I feel whilſt I am ſpeaking, you would know me to be in earneſt, and what I ſay to be the dictates of a heart that admires you. May I not ſay—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sir, this is carrying the—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
When I danced with you at Bath, I was charmed with your whole behaviour, and felt the ſame tender admiration: but my hope of ſeeing you afterwards kept in my paſſion till a more proper time ſhould
offer. You cannot therefore blame me now, if after having loſt you once, I do not ſuffer an inexcuſable modeſty to prevent my making uſe of this ſecond opportunity.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: This behaviour, ſir, is ſo different from the gaiety of your converſation then, that I am at a loſs how to anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There is nothing, madam, which could take off from the gaiety with which your preſence inſpires every heart, but the fear of loſing you. How can I be otherwiſe than as I am, when I know not, but you may leave London as abruptly as you did Bath?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Madam, the tea is ready, and my miſtreſs waits for you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Very well, I come— [Exit Lucetta.] You ſee, ſir, I am called away; but I hope you will excuſe it, when I leave you with an aſſurance, that the buſineſs which brings me to town will keep me here ſome time.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How generous it is in you thus to eaſe the heart, that knew not how to aſk for ſuch a favour—I fear to offend— but this houſe, I ſuppoſe is yours?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You will hear of me, if not find me here.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I then take my leave. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'm undone! he has me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Well! How do you find yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I do find—that if he goes on, as he has begun, I ſhall certainly have him without giving him the leaſt uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: A very terrible proſpect, indeed!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But I muſt teize him a little.—Where is Jacintha? How ſhe will laugh at me, if I become a pupil of hers, and learn to give eaſe. No! poſitively I ſhall never do it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Poor Jacintha has met with what I feared, from Mr. Strictland's temper—an utter denial. I know not why, but he really grows more and more ill-natured.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Well! now do I heartily wiſh my affairs were
in his power a little, that I might have a few difficulties to ſurmount.—I love difficulties—and yet, I don't know, it is as well as it is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Come the tea waits.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Theſe doings in my houſe diſtract me! I met a fine gentleman—when I enquired who he was; why he came to Clarinda. I met a footman too, and he came to Clarinda. I ſhall not be eaſy till ſhe is decamped. My wife had the character of a virtuous woman—and they have not been long acquainted. But then they were by themſelves at Bath! that hurts— that hurts— they muſt be watched— they muſt—I know them, I know all their wiles, and the beſt of them are but hypocrites. Ha!— [Lucetta paſſes over the ſtage.] Suppoſe I bribe the maid—ſhe is of their counſel—the manager of their ſecrets—It ſhall be ſo— money will do it, and I ſhall know all that paſſes. Lucetta!

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Sir. If he ſhould ſuſpect, and ſearch me now I'm undone. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: She is a ſly girl, and may be ſerviceable. [Aſide.] Lucetta, you are a good girl, and have an honeſt face. I like it. It looks as if it carried no deceit in it.—Yet if ſhe ſhould be falſe, ſhe can do me no harm.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Pray ſir, ſpeak out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: [Aſide.] No! ſhe is a woman, and it is the higheſt imprudence to truſt her.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: I am not able to underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I am glad of it. I would not have you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Then what did you call me for? If he ſhould be in love with my face, it would be rare ſport. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Tſter, ay, Teſter is the proper perſon—Lucetta, tell Teſter I want him.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p:
Yes, ſir.— [Aſide.] mighty odd, this! it
gives me time however to ſend Buckle with this letter to his maſter.
Exit Lucetta.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Could I but be once well ſatisfied that my wife had really finiſhed me, I believe I ſhould be as quiet, as if I were ſure of the contrary.—But whilſt I am in doubt, I am miſerable.

sp.speaker: Teſter.
sp.p: Does your honor pleaſe to want me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Ay, Teſter.—I need not fear. The honeſty of his ſervice, and the goodneſs of his look make me ſecure. I will truſt him. [Aſide.] —Teſter, I think I have been a tolerable good maſter to you?

sp.speaker: Teſter.
sp.p: Yes, ſir,— very tolerable.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: [Aſide.] I like his ſimplicity well. It promiſes honeſty—I have a ſecret to impart to you— a thing of the greateſt importance. Look upon me, and don't ſtand picking your fingers.

sp.speaker: Teſter.
sp.p: Yes, ſir,—no, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: But will not his ſimplicity expoſe him the more to Lucetta's cunning? Yes, yes! ſhe will worm the ſecret out of him. I had better truſt her with it at once.—So—I will. [Aſide.] Teſter, go ſend Lucetta hither.

sp.speaker: Teſter.
sp.p:
Yes, ſir, here ſhe is.
Re-enter Lucetta. Lucetta, my maſter wants you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Get you down, Teſter.

sp.speaker: Teſter.
sp.p:
Yes, ſir.
Exit Teſter.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: If you want me, ſir, I beg you would make haſte, for I have a thouſand things to do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Well! well! what I have to ſay will not take up much time, could I but perſuade you to be honeſt.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Why, ſir, I hope you don't ſuſpect my honeſty?

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Well! well! I believe you honeſt.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: What can be at the bottom of all this? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: So! we cannot be too private. Come hither huſſy! nearer yet.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Laud! ſir! you are not going to be rude? I vow, I will call out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Hold your tongue. Does the baggage laugh at me? [Aſide.] She does—ſhe mocks me, and will reveal it to my wife; and her inſolence upon it will be more inſupportable to me than cuckoldom itſelf I have not leiſure now, Lucetta—ſome other time—huſh! did not the bell ring? Yes, yes; my wife wants you. Go, go, go to her. [Puſhes her out.] There is no hell on earth like being a ſlave to ſuſpicion

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I would not put your family into any confuſion.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: None in life, my dear, I aſſure you. I will go and order every thing this inſtant for her reception.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: You are too obliging, ſir; but you need not be in this hurry, for I am in no certainty when I ſhall trouble you: I only know that my Jacintha has taken ſuch a reſolution.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Therefore we ſhould be prepared; for when once a lady has ſuch a reſolution in her head, ſhe is upon the rack till ſhe executes it, foregad! Mr. Bellamy, this muſt be a girl of fire.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Buxom and lively as the bounding doe.—Fair a • painting can expreſs, or youthful poets fancy when they love. Tol de rol, lol! Singing and dancing.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Who is this you talk thus rapturouſly of?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Who ſhould it be, but—I ſhall know her name to-morrow. Sings and dances.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: What is the matter, ho! Is the man mad?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Even ſo, gentlemen, as mad as love and joy can make me.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: But inform us whence this joy proceeds?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Joy! joy! my lads! ſhe's found! My Perdita! my charmer!

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Egad! her charms have bewitched the man I think—but who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Come, come, tell us who is this wonder?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But will you ſay nothing?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Nothing, as I live.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nor you?

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: I'll be as ſilent as the grave—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: With a tombſtone upon it, to tell every one whoſe duſt you carry.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: I'll be as ſecret as a debauch'd prude—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Whoſe ſanctity every one ſuſpects. Jack, Jack, 'tis not in thy nature. Keeping a ſecret is worſe to thee than keeping thy accounts. But to leave fooling, liſten to me, both, that I may whiſper it into your ears, that Echo may not catch the ſinking ſound—I cannot tell who ſhe is, 'faith—Tol de rol, lol—

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Mad! mad! very mad!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: All I know of her is, that ſhe is a charming woman, and has given me liberty to viſit her again— Bellamy, 'tis ſhe, the lovely ſhe. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p:
So I did ſuppoſe.
To Frankly.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Poor Charles! for heaven's ſake, Mr. Bellamy, perſuade him home to his chamber.—Whilſt I prepare every thing for you at home. [Aſide.] Adieu! —b'ye Charles! ha, ha, ha! Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O, Love! thou art a gift worthy of a god indeed! dear Bellamy, nothing now could add to my pleaſure, but to ſee my friend as deep in love as I am.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I ſhow my heart is capable of love, by the friendſhip it bears to you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The light of friendſhip looks but dim before the brighter flame of love. Love is the ſpring of chearfulneſs and joy. Why, how dull and phlegmatic do you ſhow to me now? whilſt I am all life; light as feather'd Mercury.—You dull, and cold as earth and water; I light and warm as air and fire.— Thoſe are the only elements in Love's world! why, Bellamy, for ſhame! get thee a miſtreſs, and be ſociable.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Frankly, I am now going to—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, that face now? your humble ſervant, ſir. My flood of joy ſhall not be ſtopt by your melancholy fits, I aſſure you. Going.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Stay, Frankly, I beg you ſtay. What would you ſay now, if I really were in love?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, faith, thou haſt ſuch romantic notions of ſenſe and honor, that I know not what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: To confeſs the truth then, I am in love.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And do you confeſs it as if it were a ſin? proclaim it loud—glory in it—boaſt of it as your greateſt virtue—ſwear it with a lover's oath, and I will believe you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Why then, by the bright eyes of her I love!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well ſaid!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: By all that's tender, amiable, and ſoft in woman—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Bravo!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I ſwear I am as true an enamorato as ever tagg'd a rhyme!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And art thou then thoroughly in love? Come to my arms, thou dear companion of my joys—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why—hey!—Is there never a wench to be got for love or money?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Pſhah! Ranger here!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Yes, Ranger is here, and perhaps does not come ſo impertinently as you may imagine. Faith! I think I have the knack of finding out ſecrets. Nay, never look ſo queer.—Here is a letter Mr. Bellamy, that ſeems to promiſe you better diverſion than your hugging one another.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Do you deal much in theſe paper tokens?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Oh! the dear kind creature! It is from her herſelf.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: What! is it a pair of lac'd ſhoes ſhe wants? or have the boys broke her windows?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Hold your prophane tongue!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay, prithee Bellamy, don't keep it to yourſelf, as if her whole affections were contained in theſe few lines.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Prithee let him alone to his ſilent raptures: but it is, as I always ſaid—your grave men ever are the greateſt whore-maſters.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I cannot be diſoblig'd now, ſay what you will. But how came this into your hands?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Your ſervant Buckle and I chang'd commiſſions. He went on my errand, and I came on his.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: S'death! I want him this very inſtant.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: He will be here preſently! but I demand to know what I have brought you?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ay! ay! out with it! you know we never blab, and may be of ſervice.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Twelve o'clock! oh! the dear hour.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why, it is a pretty convenient time, indeed.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: By all that's happy, ſhe promiſes in this letter here—to leave her guardian this very night—and run away with me.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: How is this?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Nay, I know not how myſelf— ſhe ſays at the bottom—Your ſervant has full inſtructions from Lucetta, how to equip me for my expedition—I will not truſt myſelf home with you to-night, becauſe I know it is inconvenient; therefore I beg you would procure me a lodging; it is no matter how far off my guardian's.—Yours, Jacintha.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Carry her to a bagnio, and there you may lodge with her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why this muſt be a girl of ſpirit, faith!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: And beauty equal to her ſprightlineſs. I love her, and ſhe loves me—ſhe has thirty thouſand to her fortune.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: The devil ſhe has!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: And never plays at cards—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Nor does any one thing like any one other woman I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Not ſo, I hope, neither.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Oh! Frankly, Ranger. I never felt ſuch eaſe before. The ſecret's out, and you don't laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Laugh at thee?—for loving a woman with thirty thouſand pounds! thou art a moſt unaccountable fellow.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: How the devil could he work her up to this? I never could have had the face to have done it. But— I know not how—there is a degree of aſſurance in you modeſt gentlemen, which we impudent fellows can never come up to—

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Oh! your ſervant, good ſir; you ſhould not abuſe me now, Ranger, but do all you can to aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why, look ye, Bellamy, I am a damnable unlucky fellow—and ſo will have nothing to do in this affair. I'll take care to be out of the way, ſo as to do you no harm. This is all I can anſwer for, and ſo ſucceſs attend you. [Going.] I cannot leave you quite to yourſelf neither, for if this ſhould prove a roundhouſe affair, as I make no doubt it will, I believe I may have more intereſt there than you; and ſo, ſir, you may hear of me at— Whiſpers.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: For ſhame, Ranger, the moſt noted gaming-houſe in town.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Forgive me this once, my boy. I muſt go, faith, to pay a debt of honor to ſome of the greateſt raſcals in the nation. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But where do you deſign to lodge her?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: At Mr. Meggot's—he is already gone to prepare for her reception.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The propereſt place in the world. His aunts will entertain her with honor.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: And the newneſs of our acquaintance will prevent its being ſuſpected.—Frankly, give me your hand. This is a very critical time—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pho! none of your muſty reflections now! when a man is in love to the very brink of matrimony, what the devil has he to do with Plutarch and Seneca? Here is your ſervant with a face full of buſineſs—I'll leave you together— I ſhall be at the King's Arms, where, if you want my aſſiſtance, you may find me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: So—Buckle—you ſeem to have your hands full.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Not fuller than my head, ſir, I promiſe you. You have had your letter, I hope?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Yes, and in it ſhe refers me to you for my inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Why, the affair ſtands thus—as Mr. Strictland ſees the doors lock'd and barr'd every night himſelf, and takes the keys up with him; it is impoſſible for us to eſcape any way but thro' the window: for which purpoſe I have a ladder of ropes.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Good—

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: And becauſe a hoop, as the ladies wear them now, is not the moſt decent dreſs to come down a ladder in—I have in this other bundle a ſuit of boy's cloaths, which I believe will fit her. At leaſt, it will ſerve the time ſhe will want it—you will ſoon be for pulling them off, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Bella
sp.p: Why, you are in ſpirits, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Theſe I am now to convey to Lucetta—have you any thing to ſay, ſir?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Nothing, but that I will not fail at the hour appointed—bring me word to Mr. Meggot's how you go on. Succeed in this, and it ſhall make your fortune.

div.head: SCENE I. The ſtreet before Mr. Strictland's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Bellamy in a chairman's coat.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: HOW tediouſly have the minutes paſt theſe laſt few hours! and the envious rogues will fly, no lightning quicker, when we would have them ſtay.—Hold! let me not miſtake.—This is the houſe. [Pulls out his watch.] By heaven! it is not yet the hour— I hear ſomebody coming. The moon's ſo bright—I had better not be here, 'till the happy inſtant comes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Wine is no antidote to love, but rather feeds the flame. Now am I ſuch an amorous puppy, that I cannot walk ſtraight home, but muſt come out of my way to take a view of my queen's palace by moon-light. Ay, here ſtands the temple where my goddeſs is adored! The door opens. Retires.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: [Under the window.] Madam, madam, hiſt! madam.—How ſhall I make her hear?

div.stage: Jacintha in boys clothes at the window.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Who is there? —what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p:
It is I, madam. You muſt not pretend to
ſtir till I give the word—you will be diſcovered if you do.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: [Aſide.] What do I ſee! a man. My heart miſgives me!—

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: My maſter is below fitting up for Mrs. Clarinda. He • aves as if he was mad about her being out ſo late.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Here is ſome intrigue or other. I muſt ſee more of this, before I give further way to love.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: One minute he is in the ſtreet—the next he is in the kitchen. Now he will lock her out, and then he will wait himſelf and ſee what figure ſhe makes when ſhe vouchſafes to venture home.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I long to have it over. Get me but once out of this houſe!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Cowardly raſcal! would I were in his place.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: If I can but fix him any where, I can let you out myſelf—you have the ladder ready in caſe of neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p:
Yes! yes!
Exit Lucetta.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: [Aſide.] The ladder! This muſt lead to ſome diſcovery. I ſhall watch you my young gentleman, I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: This whift is a moſt enticing devil. I am afraid I am too late for Mr. Strictland's ſober hours.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Ha! I hear a noiſe!
