sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No! I ſee a light in Jacintha's widow. You may go home. [Giving the ſervant money.] I am ſafe.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Sure it muſt be he! Mr. Bellamy.—Sir!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Does not he call to me?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Ha! who's that? I am frighted out of my wits.—A man!—

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Is it you?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes! yes! 'tis I! tis I!

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Liſten at the door.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I will, 'tis open—there is no noiſe—all's quiet.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sure it is my ſpark—and talking to Jacintha.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You may come down the ladder—quick.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Catch it then and hold it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I have it. Now I ſhall ſee what ſort of mettle my young ſpark is made of. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: With a ladder too! I'll aſſure you. But I muſt ſee the end of it. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Hark! did not ſome body ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No! no! be not fearful—'ſdeath! we are diſcovered. Frankly and Clarinda retire.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Hiſt! hiſt! are you ready?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Yes, may I venture?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p:
Now is your time. He is in high conference with his privy counſellor Mr. Teſter. You may come down the back ſtairs, and I'll let you out.
Exit. Lucet.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I will, I will, and am heartily glad of it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: [Advancing.] May be ſo—but you and I ſhall have a few words before you get off ſo cleanly.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: [Advancing.] How lucky it was I came home at this inſtant. I ſhall ſpoil his ſport, I believe. Do you know me, ſir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I am amazed! you here! This was unexpected indeed!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why, I believe I do come a little unexpectedly; but I ſhall amaze you more—I know the whole courſe of your amour; all the proceſs of your mighty paſſion from its firſt riſe—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What is all this!—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: To the very concluſion, which you vainly hope to effect this night.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: By heaven, madam, I know not what you mean. I came hither purely to contemplate on your beauties.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Any beauties, ſir, I find will ſerve your turn. Did I not hear you talk to her at the window?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Her!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Bluſh, bluſh for ſhame; but be aſſured you have ſeen the laſt both of Jacintha and me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Jacintha! hear me, madam—ſhe is gone. This muſt certainly be Bellamy's miſtreſs, and I have fairly ruin'd all his ſcheme. This it is to be in luck.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Ha! a man under the window!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, here ſhe comes, and I may convey her to him.

div.stage: Enter Jacintha, and runs to Frankly.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I have at laſt got to you: let's haſte away —oh!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Be not frighten'd, lady.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Oh! I am abus'd, betray'd!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Betray'd! Frankly!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I can ſcarce believe it, tho' I ſee it. Draw—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Hear me, Bellamy— lady.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Stay—do not fight.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I am innocent; it is all a miſtake.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: For my ſake be quiet—we ſhall be diſcovered. The family is alarmed.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: You are obeyed—Mr. Frankly, there is but one way—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I underſtand you. Any time but now. You will certainly be diſcovered. To morrow—at your chambers.—

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p:
'Till then, farewell.
Exeunt Bella. and Jacin.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Then, when he is cool, I may be heard; and the real, tho' ſuſpicious account of this matter may be believed. Yet amidſt all this perplexity, it pleaſes me to find my fair incognita is jealous of my love.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: [Within.] Where's Lucetta? Search every place.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Hark! the cry is up.—I muſt be gone.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Strictland, Teſter, and ſervants.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: She's gone! ſhe's loſt! I am cheated! purſue her! ſeek her!

sp.speaker: Teſter.
sp.p: Sir, all her cloaths are in her chamber.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Mrs. Clarinda ſaid ſhe was in boy's cloaths.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Ay, ay! I know it—Bellamy has her— come along—purſue her. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
Hark!—was not the noiſe this way— no—there is no game ſtirring. This ſame goddeſs Diana, ſhines ſo bright with her chaſtity, that egad! I
believe the wenches are aſham'd to look her in the face. Now am I in an admirable mood for a frolic! I have wine in my head, and money in my pocket, and am ſo furniſh'd out for the cannonading any counteſs in Chriſtendom! ha! what have we here! a ladder! this cannot be placed here for nothing—and a window open! —Is it love, or miſchief now that is going on within? —I care not which—I am in a right cue for either. Up I go—Stay,—do I not run a greater chance of ſpoiling ſport than I do of making any? that I hate as much as I love the other—There can be no harm in ſeeing how the laud lies—I'll up. [Goes up ſoftly.] —All is huſh!— ha! a light! and a woman, by all that's lucky, neither old, nor crooked—I'll in—ha! ſhe is gone again! I will after her. [Gets in at the window.] And for fear of the ſquawls of virtue, and the purſuit of the family, I will make ſure of the ladder. Now, fortune be my guide. Exit with the ladder.

div.head: SCENE II. Mrs. Strictland's Dreſſing-Room.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Strictland, follow'd by Lucetta.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Well! I am in great hopes ſhe will eſcape.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Never fear, madam. The lovers have the ſtart of him, and I warrant, they keep it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Were Mr. Strictland ever to ſuſpect my being privy to her flight, I know not what might be the conſequence.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Then you had better be undreſſing—He may return immediately—

div.stage: As ſhe is ſitting down to the toilet, Ranger enters behind.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Young and beautiful.— Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: I have watched him pretty narrowly of late, and never once ſuſpected till this morning—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: And who gave you authority to watch his actions, or pry into his ſecrets?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: I hope madam, you are not angry? I thought it might have been of ſervice to you to know my maſter was jealous.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: And her huſband jealous! if ſhe does but ſend away the maid, I am happy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: [Angrily.] Leave me!

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: This it is to meddle with other peoples affairs.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: What a lucky dog I am! I never made a gentlemen a cuckold before. Now, Impudence aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: [Riſing.] Provoking! I am ſure I never have deſerved it of him.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Oh cuckold him by all means, madam, I am your man! [She ſh • ieks.] Oh, fy, madam! if you ſquawl ſo curſedly, you will be diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Diſcovered! What mean you, ſir? Do you come to abuſe me?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I'll do my endeavours, madam: you can have no more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Whence came you? How got you here?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Dear madam, ſo long as I am here, what ſignifies how I got here, or whence I came? But that I may ſatisfy your curioſity. Firſt, as to your whence came you? I anſwer, out of the ſtreet: and to your how got you here? I ſay, in at the window. It ſtood ſo invitingly open, it was irreſiſtible. But, madam,— you was going to undreſs. I beg I may not incommode you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: This is the moſt conſummate piece of impudence!—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, have one drop of pity for a poor young fellow, who long has lov'd you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: What would the fellow have?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Your huſband's uſage will excuſe you to the world.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I cannot bear this inſolence, help! help!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Oh! hold that clamorous tongue! madam, ſpeak one word more, and I am gone, poſitively gone!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Gone! ſo I would have you.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Lord! madam, you are ſo haſty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict
sp.p: Shall I not ſpeak, when a thief, a robber breaks into my houſe at midnight? help! help!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ha! no one hears. Now, Cupid, aſſiſt me! look ye, madam, I never could make fine ſpeeches, and and cringe, and bow, and fawn, and flatter, and lye, I have ſaid more to you already, than I ever ſaid to a woman in ſuch circumſtances in all my life. But ſince I find you will yield to no perſuaſion to your good— I will gently force you to be grateful. [throws down his hat, and ſeizes her.] Come, come! unbend that brow, and look more kindly on me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: For ſhame, ſir—thus on my knees, let me beg for mercy. Kneeling.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: And thus, on mine, let me beg the ſame.

div.stage: He kneels, catches and kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: [within.] Take away her ſword! ſhe'll hurt herſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Oh! heavens! that is my huſband's voice!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: [Riſing.] The devil it is!

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: [within.] Take away her ſword, I ſay, and then I can cloſe with her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: He is upon the ſtairs, now coming up. I am undone, if he ſees you.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Pox on him! I muſt decamp then. Which way?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Thro' this paſſage into the next chamber.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: And ſo into the ſtreet. With all my heart. You may be perfectly eaſy, madam. Mum's the word. I never blab— [Aſide.] I ſhall never leave off ſo, but wait till the laſt moment. Exit Ranger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: So, he is gone! What could I have ſaid, if he had been diſcovered!

div.stage: Enter Mr. Strictland, driving in Jacintha, Lucetta following.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Once more, my pretty maſculine madam, you are welcome home. And I hope to keep you ſomewhat cloſer than I have done: for to-morow morning, eight o'clock, is the lateſt hour you ſhall ſtay in this lewd town.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p:
Oh, ſir! when once a girl is equipped with a hearty reſolution, it is not your worſhip's ſagacity, nor
the great chain at your gate can hinder her from doing what ſhe has a mind.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Oh, lord! lord! how this love improves a young lady's modeſty.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Am I to blame to ſeek for happineſs any where, when you are reſolved to make me miſerable here!

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I have this night prevented your making yourſelf ſo; and will endeavour to do it for the future. I have you ſafe now, and the devil ſhall not get you out of my clutches again. I have lock'd the doors and barr'd them, I warrant you. So, here— [giving her a candle.] Troop to your chamber, and to bed, whilſt you are well, go— [He treads on Ranger's hat.] What's here? a hat! a man's hat in my wife's dreſſing-room!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: [Aſide.] What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: [Taking up the hat, and looking at Mrs. Strictland.] Ha! by hell! I ſee 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: My fears confound me. I dare not tell the truth, and know not how to frame a lye!

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Mrs. Strictland! Mrs. Strictland! how came this hat into your chamber!

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Are you that way diſpos'd, my fine lady, and will not truſt me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Speak, wretch, ſpeak.—

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I could not have ſuſpected this. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Why doſt thou not ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Guilt—'tis guilt that ties your tongue!

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: I muſt bring her off, however—no chamber-maid can help it.— Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: My fears are juſt, and I am miſerable— thou worſt of women!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I know my innocence, and can bear this no longer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I know you are falſe,—and 'tis I who will bear my injuries no longer.

div.stage: Both walk about in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: [To Jacintha aſide.] Is not the hat yours? own it, madam.

div.stage: Takes away Jacintha's hat, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p:
What ground? what cauſe have you
for jealouſy, when you yourſelf can witneſs, your leaving me was accidental; your return uncertain; and expected even ſooner than it happen'd? the abuſe is groſs and palpable.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Why, this is true!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Indeed, Jacintha, I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: And yet this hat muſt belong to ſomebody.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Dear, Mrs. Strictland, be not concern'd when he has diverted himſelf a little longer with it—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe he will give me my hat again?

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Your hat?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Yes, my hat. You bruſh'd it from my ſide yourſelf, and then trod upon it; whether on purpoſe to abuſe this lady or no, you beſt know yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: It cannot be.—It's all a lye.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Believe ſo ſtill—with all my heart—but the hat is mine. Snatches it and puts it on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Why did ſhe look ſo?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Your violence of temper is too much for her. You uſe her ill, and then ſuſpect her for that confuſion which you yourſelf occaſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Why did not you ſet me right at firſt?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Your hard uſage of me, ſir, is a ſufficient reaſon why I ſhould not be much concern'd to undeceive you at all. 'Tis for your lady's ſake, I do it now; who deſerves much better of you than to be thus expos'd for every ſlight ſuſpicion. See where ſhe ſits—go to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: [Riſing.] Indeed, Mr. Strictland, I have a ſoul as much above—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Whew! now you have both found your tongues, and I muſt bear their eternal rattle!

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: For ſhame! ſir, go to her, and—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Well! well! what ſhall I ſay? I forgive —all is over. I, I, I forgive!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Forgive! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Forgive her? is that all? conſider, ſir—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p:
Hold —hold your confounded tongues, and I'll do any thing. I'll aſk pardon—or forgive—or any thing. Good now, be quiet—I aſk your pardon—
there— [Kiſſes her.] For you, madam—I am infinitely oblig • d to you, and I could find in my heart to make you a return in kind, by marrying you to a beggar,— but I have more conſcience. Come, come; to your chamber.—Here take this candle—

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Sir, if you pleaſe, I will light my young lady to bed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: No! no! no ſuch thing, good madam. She ſhall have nothing but her pillow to conſult this night, I aſſure you—ſo in, in. [The ladies take leave.] [Exit Jacintha.] Good night, kind madam.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Pox of the jealous fool! we might both have eſcaped out of the window purely. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Go, get you down and do you hear; order the coach to be ready in the morning at eight exactly. [Exit Lucetta.] [Locks the door after her.] So ſhe is ſafe till to-morrow, and then for the country; and when ſhe is there, I can manage as I think fit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Strictland—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I am not in a humour, Mrs. Strictland, fit to talk with you.—Go to bed, I will endeavour to get the better of my temper, if I can—I'll follow you! [Exit Mrs. Strictland.] How deſpicable have I made myſelf! Exit.

div.head: SCENE III. Another CHAMBER.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: All ſeems huſh'd again, and I may venture out. I may as well ſneak off whilſt I am in a whole ſkin. And ſhall ſo much love and claret as I am in poſſeſſion of, only lull me to ſleep, when it might ſo much better keep me waking? forbid it, Fortune; and forbid it, Love. This is a chamber, perhaps of ſome bewitching female, and I may yet be happy. Ha! a light! the door opens. A boy! pox on him.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I have been liſtening at the door; and from their ſilence, I conclude they are peaceably gone to bed together.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: [Aſide.] A pretty boy, faith! he ſeems uneaſy.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: [Sitting down.] What an unlucky night has this proved to me! every circumſtance has fallen out unhappily.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: He talks aloud. I'll liſten. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: But what moſt amazes me is, that Clarinda ſhould betray me!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Clarinda? She muſt be a woman! well! what of her? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: My guardian elſe would never have ſuſpected my diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Diſguiſe! ha! it muſt be ſo. What eyes ſhe has? What a dull rogue was I not to ſuſpect this ſooner?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Ha! I had forgot the ladder is at the window ſtill, and I will boldly venture by myſelf. [Riſing briſkly, ſees Ranger.] Ha! a man! and well dreſt! ha! Mrs. Strictland, are you then at laſt diſhoneſt?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: [Aſide.] By all my wiſhes ſhe is a charming woman! lucky raſcal!

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: But I will if poſſible, conceal her ſhame, and ſtand the brunt of his impertinence.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay to her? no matter; any thing ſoft will do the buſinesſ.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: A man, young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: And what would you have?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: A woman.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: You are very free, ſir. Here are none for you.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ay, but there is one, and a fair one too; the moſt charming creature Nature ever ſet her hand to; and you are the dear little pilot, that muſt direct me to her heart.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: What mean you, ſir? It is an office I am not accuſtom'd to.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
You won't have far to go, however. I never
make my errands tedious! it is to your own heart. Dear madam, I would have you whiſper in my behalf. Nay, never ſtart. Think you ſuch beauty could ever be conceal'd from eyes ſo well acquainted with its charms?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: What will become of me! if I cry out Mrs. Strictland is undone, that is my laſt reſort.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Pardon, dear lady, the boldneſs of this viſit, which your guardian's care has forced me to— but I long have lov'd you, long doated on that beauteous face, and follow'd you from place to place, tho' perhaps, unknown and unregarded.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Here's a ſpecial fellow! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Turn then an eye of pity on my ſufferings; and by heaven—one tender look from thoſe piercing eyes— one touch of this ſoft hand—

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Hold, ſir—no nearer.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Would more than repay whole years of pain.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Hear me. But keep your diſtance, or I raiſe the family.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Bleſſings on her tongue, only for prattling to me. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Oh! for a moment's courage, and I ſhall ſhame him from his purpoſe. [Aſide.] If I were certain ſo much gallantry had been ſhown on my account only.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: You wrong your beauty to think that any other could have power to draw me hither. By all the little loves that play about your lips I ſwear—

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: You came to me, and me alone?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: By all the thouſand graces that inhabit there, you, and only you have drawn me hither.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Well ſaid.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: By heaven ſhe comes! ah! honeſt Ranger, I never knew thee fail!— Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, where did you leave this hat?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: That hat!—that hat—It's my hat. — I dropt it in the next chamber as I was looking for yours.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: How mean and deſpicable do you look now?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: So! ſo! I am in a pretty pickle! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: You know by this, that I am acquainted with every thing that has paſſed within: and how ill it agrees with what you have profeſ • ed to me—let me adviſe you, ſir, to be gone immediately. Thro' that window you may eaſily get into the ſtreet—one ſcream of mine; the leaſt noiſe at that door will wake the houſe.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Say you ſo? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Believe me, ſir, an inju •• d huſband is not ſo eaſily appeas'd, and a ſuſpected wife that is jealous of her honor—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Is the devil, and ſo let us hear no more of her. Look ye, madam, [Going between the door and her.] I have but one argument left, and that is a ſtrong one. Look on me well, I am as handſome a ſtrong well-made fellow as any about town, and ſince we are alone, as I take it, we can have no occaſion to be more private.

div.stage: Going to lay hold of her.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I have a reputation, ſir, and will maintain it.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: You have a bewitching pair of eyes.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Conſider my virtue. Struggling.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Conſider your beauty and my deſires.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: If I were a man, you dar'd not uſe me thus.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I ſhould not have had the ſame temptation.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Hear me, ſir, I will be heard. [Breaks from him.] There is a man who will make you repent this uſage of me.—Oh! Bellamy, where art thou now?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Were he here you durſt not thus affront me.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: His miſtreſs on my ſoul! [Aſide.] You can love madam; you can love, I find. Her tears affect me ſtrangely. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I am not aſhamed to own my paſſion for a man of virtue and honor.—I love and glory in it.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: O! brave! and you can write letters, you can. I will not truſt myſelf home with you this evening, becauſe I know it is inconvenient.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
Therefore I beg you would procure me a lodging;
it's no matter how far off my guardian's. Yours, Jacintha.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: The very words of my letter! I am amazed. Do you know Mr. Bellamy?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: There is not a man on earth I have ſo great a value for: and he muſt have ſome value for me too, or he would never have ſhown me your pretty epiſtle. Think of that, fair lady. The ladder is at the window. And ſo madam, I hope delivering you ſafe into his arms will, in ſome meaſure, expiate the crime I have been guilty of to you.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Good heaven, how fortunate is this?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I believe I make myſelf appear more wicked than I really am. For, damn me, if I do not feel more ſatisfaction in the thoughts of reſtoring you to my friend, than I could have pleaſure in any favour your bounty could have beſtowed.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Your generoſity tranſports me.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Let us loſe no time then, the ladder is ready. —Where was you to lodge?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: At Mr. Meggot's.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: At my friend Jacky's? better and better ſtill.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Are you acquainted with him too?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ay, ay! why did I not tell you at firſt that I was one of your old acquaintance? I know all about you, you ſee; tho' the devil fetch me if ever I ſaw you before. Now Madam—

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: And now, ſir,— have with you.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Then thou art a girl of ſpirit. And tho' I long to hug you for truſting yourſelf with me, I will not beg a ſingle kiſs, till Bellamy himſelf ſhall give me leave. He muſt fight well that takes you from me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: PSHA! what impertinent devil put it into your head to meddle with my affairs?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You know I went thither in purſuit of another.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I know nothing you had to do there at all.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I thought Mr. Bellamy you were a lover.

sp.speaker: Bella
sp.p: I am ſo; and therefore ſhould be forgiven this ſudden warmth.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And therefore ſhould forgive the fond impertinence of a lover.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Jealouſy, you know, is as natural an incident to love—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: As curioſity. By one piece of ſilly curioſity I have gone nigh to ruin both myſelf and you. Let not then your jealouſy complete our misfortunes! I fear I have loſt a miſtreſs as well as you. Then let us not quarrel. All may come right again.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: It is impoſſible. She is gone, remov'd for ever from my ſight. She is in the country by this time.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How did you loſe her after we parted?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: By too great confidence. When I got her to my chair, the chairmen were not to be found.—And ſafe, as I thought in our diſguiſe, I actually put her into the chair, when Mr. Strictland and his ſervants were in ſight; which I had no ſooner done, than they ſurrounded us, overpowered me, and carried her away.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Unfortunate indeed! could you not make a ſecond attempt?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p:
I had deſigned it. But when I came to the door, I found the ladder removed; and hearing no noiſe, ſeeing no lights, nor being able to make any body anſwer, I concluded all attempts as impracticable as now I find them. Ha! I ſee Lucetta coming. Then they may be ſtill in town.
Enter Lucetta. Lucetta welcome! what news of Jacintha?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: News, ſir! you fright me out of my ſenſes! why is ſhe not with you?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What do you mean? With me! I have not ſeen her ſince I loſt her laſt night.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Good heaven! then ſhe is undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Speak out—I'm all amazement.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p:
She is eſcaped without any of us knowing how. Nobody miſs'd her 'till morning. We all thought
ſhe went away with you. But heaven knows now what may have happen'd!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Somebody muſt have accompanied her in her flight.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: We know of nobody. We are all in confuſion at home. My maſter ſwears revenge on you. My miſtreſs ſays a ſtranger has her.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: A ſtranger!

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: But Mrs. Clarinda—

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Clarinda! who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: [To Frankly.] The lady, ſir, you ſaw at our houſe laſt night.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ha! what of her?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: She ſays ſhe is ſure one Frankly, is the man. She ſaw them together, and knows it to be true.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Damn'd fortune!

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Sure this is not Mr. Frankly?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nothing will convince him now. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: [looking at Frankly.] Ha! 'tis truth—I ſee it is true. [Aſide.] Lucetta run up to Buckle, and take him with you to ſearch wherever you can. [Puts her out.] Now, Mr. Frankly, I have found you.—You have uſed me ſo ill, that you force me to forget you are my friend.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Draw.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Are you mad? By heavens! I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I have heard you, and will no longer be impos'd on.—Defend yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay, if you are ſo hot, I draw to defend myſelf, as I would againſt a madman.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: What the devil, ſwords at noonday! Have among you, faith! [parts them.] What's here, Bellamy?—Yes, gad, you are Bellamy, and you are Frankly. Put up, put up both of you—or elſe—I am a deviliſh fellow when once my ſword is out.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: We ſhall have a time—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: [Puſhing Bellamy one way.] a time for what?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I ſhall be always as ready to defend my innocence as now.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
[Puſhing Frankly t'other way.] Innocence!
ay, to be ſure!—at your age!—a mighty innocent fellow, no doubt. But what in the name of common ſenſe is it that ails you both? Are you mad? The laſt time I ſaw you, you were hugging and kiſſing; and now you are cutting one another's throats—I never knew any good come of one fellow's be ſlavering another— But I ſhall put you into better humour, I warrant you. Bellamy, Frankly, liſten both of you—ſuch fortune— ſuch a ſcheme—

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Pr'ythee, leave fooling! what, art drunk?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He is always ſo, I think.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: And who gave you the privilege of thinking? Drunk! no! I am not drunk—tipſy perhaps, with my good fortune—merry and in ſpirits—tho' I have not fire enough to run my friend thro' the body. Not drunk, tho' Jack Meggot and I have box'd it about —Champaign was the word for two whole hours, by Shrewſbury clock.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Jack Meggot! Why I left him at one going to bed.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: That may be, but I made a ſhift to rouſe him and his family, by four this morning. Ounds! I pick'd up a wench and carried her to his houſe.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Such a variety of adventures—nay, you ſhall hear. But before I begin Bellamy, you ſhall promiſe me half a dozen kiſſes before hand, for the devil fetch me, if that little jade, Jacintha, would give me one, tho' I preſſed hard.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Who, Jacintha? Preſs to kiſs Jacintha!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Kiſs her! ay, why not? Is ſhe not a woman, and made to be kiſſed.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Kiſs her!—I ſhall run diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: How could I help it, when I had her alone, you rogue, in her bed-chamber at midnight? If I had been to be ſacrificed, I ſhould have done it.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Bed-chamber at midnight? I can hold no longer.—Draw.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Be eaſy, Bellamy. Interpoſing.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: He has been at ſome of his damn'd tricks with her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Hear him out.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! how could I know ſhe was his miſtreſs? But I tell this ſtory moſt miſerably. I ſhould have told you firſt, I was in another lady's chamber. By the lord, I got in at the window by a ladder of ropes.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ha! another lady?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Another. And ſtole in upon her, whilſt ſhe was undreſſing; beautiful as an angel, blooming and young—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What, in the ſame houſe?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What is this to Jacintha? Eaſe me of my pain.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ay, ay, in the ſame houſe, on the ſame floor. The ſweeteſt, little angel—but I deſign to have another touch with her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! but you ſhall have a touch with me firſt.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Stay, Frankly. Interpoſing.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why, what ſtrange madneſs has poſſeſs'd you both, that no-body muſt kiſs a pretty wench but yourſelves.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: But what became of Jacintha?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ounds! what have you done that you muſt monopolize kiſſing?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pr'ythee, honeſt Ranger, eaſe me of the pain I am in. Was her name Clarinda?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Speak, in plain words, where Jacintha is, where to be found—dear boy, tell me.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ay, now it is, honeſt Ranger; and dear boy, tell me—and a minute ago, my throat was to be cut. —I could find in my heart not to open my lips. But here comes Jack Meggot, who will let you into all the ſecret, tho' he deſign'd to keep it from you, in half the time that I can, tho' I had ever ſo great a mind to tell it you.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: So, ſave ye! ſave ye, lads! we have been frighten'd out of our wits for you. Not hearing of Mr. Bellamy, poor Jacintha is ready to ſink for fear of any accident.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Is ſhe at your houſe?

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Why, did you not know that? We diſpatch'd maſter Ranger to you three hours ago.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ay, plague! but I had buſineſs of my own, and ſo I could not come. Hark ye, Frankly, is your girl maid, wife, or widow?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A maid, I hope.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: The odds are againſt you, Charles.—But mine is married, you rogue, and her huſband jealous. —The devil is in it, if I do not yet reap ſome reward for my laſt night's ſervice.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: He has certainly been at Mrs. Strictland herſelf. But Frankly, I dare not look on you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: This one embrace cancels all thoughts of enmity.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Thou generous man:—but I muſt haſte to eaſe Jacintha of her fears. Exit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And I to make up matters with Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: And I to ſome kind wench or other, Jack. But where I ſhall find her, heaven knows. And ſo, my ſervice to your monkey.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Adieu, rattle pate. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. The Hall of Mr. Strictland's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: But, why in ſuch a hurry, my dear? ſtay till your ſervants can go along with you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O, no matter! they'll follow with my things. It is but a little way off, and my chair will guard me. After my ſtaying out ſo late laſt night, I am ſure Mr. Strictland will think every minute an age whilſt I am in his houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I am as much amaz'd at his ſuſpecting your innocence as my own: and every time I think of it, I bluſh at my preſent behaviour to you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No ceremony, dear child.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: No Clarinda, I am too well acquainted with your good humour. But I fear in the eye of a malicious world, it may look like a confirmation of his ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: My dear, if the world will ſpeak ill of me, for the little innocent gaiety, which I think the peculiar happineſs of my temper, I know no way to prevent it; and am only ſorry the world is ſo ill-natur'd: but I ſhall not part with my mirth, I aſſure them, ſo long as I know it innocent. I wiſh, my dear, this may be the greateſt uneaſineſs your huſband's jealouſy ever gives you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I hope he never again may have ſuch occaſion, as he had laſt night.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You are ſo unfaſhionable a wife!—why, laſt night's accident would have made half the wives in London eaſy for life. Has not his jealouſy diſcover'd itſelf openly? and are not you innocent? there is nothing but your fooliſh temper that prevents his being abſolutely in your power.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Clarinda, this is too ſerious an affair to laugh at. Let me adviſe you, take care of Mr. Frankly, obſerve his temper well; and if he has the leaſt taint of jealouſy, caſt him off, and never truſt to keeping him in your power.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You will hear little more of Frankly, I believe. Here is Mr. Strictland.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Lucetta ſays you want me, madam.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I troubled you, ſir, only that I might return you thanks for the civilities I have received in your family, before I took my leave.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Keep them to yourſelf, dear madam. As it is at my requeſt that you leave my houſe, your thanks upon that occaſion are not very deſirable.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, you need not fear, my thanks were only for your civilities. They will not overburden you. But I'll conform to your humour, ſir, and part with as little ceremony.—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: As we met.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
The brute! [Aſide.] My dear, good-b'ye, we may meet again.
To Mrs. Strictland.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: If you dare truſt me with your hand.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Lucetta, remember my inſtructions. Now, ſir, have with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Are her inſtructions cruel or kind, Lucetta? for I ſuppoſe they relate to Mr. Frankly.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: You have a mind to try, if I can keep a ſecret, as well as yourſelf, madam. But I will ſhow you I am fit to be truſted by keeping this, tho' it ſignifies nothing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: This anſwer is not ſo civil, I think.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: I beg pardon, madam. I meant it not to offend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Pray let us have no more ſuch. I neither deſire, nor want you aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: She is gone. I feel myſelf ſomewhat eaſier already. Since I have begun the day with gallantry, madam, ſhall I conduct you up?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: There is ſomething, ſir, which gives you ſecret uneaſineſs. I wiſh—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Perhaps ſo, madam, and perhaps it may ſoon be no ſecret at all. Leads her out.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Would I were once well ſettled with my young lady; for at preſent, this is but an odd ſort of a queer family. Laſt night's affair puzzles me. A hat there was that belong'd to none of us, that's certain. Madam was in a fright, that is as certain; and I brought all off. Jacintha eſcap'd, no one of us knows how. The good man's jealouſy was yeſterday groundleſs; yet today, in my mind, he is very much in the right. Mighty odd, all this! Somebody knocks! If this ſhould be Clarinda's ſpark, I have an odd meſſage for him too.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So, my pretty handmaid. Meeting with you gives me ſome hopes. May I ſpeak with Clarinda?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Whom do you want, ſir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Clarinda, child. The young lady I was admitted to yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Clarinda?—No ſuch perſon lives here, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Where then?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: I don't know, indeed, ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Will you enquire within?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Nobody knows in this houſe, ſir, you'll find.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
What do you mean? She is a friend of Jacintha's
your lady. I will take my oath ſhe was here laſt night; and you yourſelf ſpoke of her being here this morning—not know!

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: No. None of us know. She went away of a ſudden. No one of us can imagine whither.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, faith, child, thou haſt a tolerable face, and haſt delivered this denial very handſomely. But let me tell you, your damned impertinence this morning had like to have coſt me my life. Now, therefore, make me amends. I come from your young miſtreſs, I come from Mr. Bellamy. I come with my purſe full of gold (that perſuaſive rhetoric) to win you to let me ſee, and ſpeak to this Clarinda once again.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: She is not here, ſir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Direct me to her.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: No! I can't do that neither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I heard a knocking at the door, and a man's voice—ha! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Deliver this letter to her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: By all my fears; a letter! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: I don't know but I may be tempted to do that.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Take it then—and with it this.

div.stage: Kiſſes her, and gives her money.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Um! there are two bribes in a breath! What a jade ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Ay! this gentleman underſtands reaſon!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And be aſſured you oblige your miſtreſs, while you are ſerving me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Her miſtreſs?—Damn'd ſex! and damned wife, thou art an epitome of that ſex!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
And if you can procure me an anſwer, your ſee ſhall be enlarged.
Exit Frankly.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: The next ſtep is to get her to read this letter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: [Snatches the letter.] No noiſe—but ſtand ſilent there, whilſt I read this.
sp.stage: Breaks it open, and drops the caſe.
sp.p:
Madam, the gaiety of a heart happy as mine was yeſterday, may, I hope, eaſily excuſe the unſeaſonable viſit I made your houſe laſt night. — Death and the devil! confuſion, I ſhall run diſtracted. It is too much! there
was a man then to whom the hat belong'd; and I was gull'd, abus'd, cheated, impos'd on by a chit, a girl— oh woman! woman!—But I will be calm, ſearch it cooly to the bottom, and have a full revenge.—

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: [Aſide.] So here's a fine work! he'll make himſelf very ridiculous tho'!

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: [Reads on.] I know my innocence will appear ſo manifeſtly, that I need only appeal to the lady who accompanied you at Bath. Your very humble ſervant, good, innocent, fine madam Clarinda — And I do not doubt but her good-nature, [Bawd! bawd!] will not let you perſiſt injuring your obedient humble ſervant, Charles Frankly.

Now, who can ſay my jealouſy lack'd foundation, or my ſuſpicion of ſine madam's innocent gaiety was unjuſt—gaiety? why, ay! 'twas gaiety brought him hither. Gaiety makes her a bawd—my wife may be a whore in gaiety. What a number of ſins become faſhionable under the notion of gaiety — What! You received this epiſtle in gaiety too; and were to deliver it to my wife I ſuppoſe, when the gay fit came next upon her? Why▪ you impudent young ſtrumpet, do you laugh at me!

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: I would, if I dared, and heartily—be pleas'd, ſir, only to look at that piece of paper that lies there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: I have not touched it, ſir. It is the caſe that letter came in, and the direction will inform you whom I was to deliver it to.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: This is directed to Clarinda?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Oh! is it ſo? Now read it over again, and all your fooliſh doubts will vaniſh.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I have no doubts at all. I am ſatisfied that you, Jacintha, Clarinda, my wife, all are—

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Lud! lud! you would make a body mad?

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Hold your impertinent tongue.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: You'll find the thing to be juſt as I ſay, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p:
• egone. [Exit Lucetta.] They muſt be poor at the work, indeed, if they did not lend one another their names. 'Tis plain, 'tis evident: and I am miſerable. But for my wife, ſhe ſhall not ſtay one
night longer in my houſe. Separation, ſhame, contempt ſhall be her portion. I am determined in the thing; and when once it is over, I may perhaps be eaſy. Exit.

div.head: SCENE III. The STREET.
div.stage: Enter Clarinda, in a chair, Ranger following.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Hark ye, chairmen! Damn your confounded trot. Go ſlower.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Here, ſtop.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: By heavens the monſters hear reaſon, and obey.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: [Letting down the window.] What troubleſome fellow was that?

sp.speaker: 1 Chairm.
sp.p: Some rake, I warrant, that cannot carry himſelf home, and wants us to do it for him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: There— and pray do you take care I be not troubled with him. Goes in.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: That's as much as to ſay now, pray follow me. Madam, you are a charming woman, and I will do it—

sp.speaker: 1 Chairm.
sp.p: Stand off, ſir.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Pr'ythee, honeſt fellow—what—what writing is that? Endeavouring to get in

sp.speaker: 2 Chairm.
sp.p: You come not in here!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Lodgings to be let! a pretty convenient inſcription, and the ſign of a good modeſt family! There may be lodgings for gentlemen as well as ladies. Hark ye, rogues! I'll lay you all the ſilver I have in my pocket, there it is, I get in there in ſpight of your teeth, ye pimps? Throws down money and goes in.

sp.speaker: 1 Chairm.
sp.p: What, have you let the gentleman in?

sp.speaker: 2 Chairm.
sp.p: I'll tell you what, partner, he certainly ſlipt by whilſt we were picking up the money. Come take up.

div.head: SCENE IV. CLARINDA'S LODGINGS.
div.stage: A noiſe without between Ranger and Landlady.
Clarinda enters laughing, a Maid following.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
My madcap couſin Ranger, as I live. I am
ſure he does not know me.—If I could but hide my face now, what ſport I ſhould have! a maſk, a maſk! run and ſee if you can find a maſk.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I believe there is one above.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Run, run, and fetch it. Exit Maid.

Here he comes!
Enter Ranger and Landlady.
How unlucky this is! Turning from 'em.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: What's your buſineſs here, unmannerly ſir?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Well, let's ſee theſe lodgings that are to be let. —Gad, a very pretty neat tenement!—but hark ye, is it real and natural, all that, or only patch'd up and new-painted this ſummer-ſeaſon againſt the town fills?

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: What does the ſaucy fellow mean with his double tenders here? get you down—

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p:
Here is a very dirty one.
Aſide to Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No matter—now we ſhall ſee a little what he would be at. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: This is an honeſt houſe—for all your lac'd waiſtcoat, I'll have you thrown down neck and heels.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Phoh! not in ſuch a hurry good old lady— a maſk! — nay, with all my heart. It ſaves a world of bluſhing—have you ne'er a one for me?—I am apt to be aſham'd myſelf, on theſe occaſions.

sp.speaker: Landl.
sp.p: Get you down, I ſay—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
Not if I gueſs right, old lady. Madam, [To Clarinda, who makes ſigns to the Landlady.] Look ye there now! that a woman ſhould live to your age, and know ſo little of the matter. Be gone. [Exit Landlady.] By her forwardneſs, this ſhould be a whore of quality. My boy Ranger, thou art in luck to-day.—She won't ſpeak, I find—then I will. [Aſide.] Delicate lodgings truly, madam; and very neatly furniſh'd.—A very convenient room this, I muſt needs own, to entertain a mix'd company— but my dear charming creature, does not that door open to a more commodious apartment for the happineſs of a private friend, or ſo? the prettieſt braſs lock.— Faſt, um! that won't do. 'Sdeath, you are a beautiful woman! I am ſure you are. Pr'y-thee let me ſee your face. It is your intereſt child.— The longer you delay, the more I ſhall expect. Therefore, [taking her hand.] my dear, ſoft, kind, new acquaintance,
thus let me take your hand, and whilſt you gently with the other, let day-light in upon me: let me ſoftly hold you to me, that with my longing lips I may receive the warmeſt, beſ • impreſſion. [She unmaſks.] Clarinda!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ha! ha! your ſervant, couſin Ranger: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Oh! your humble ſervant, madam! you had liked to have been beholden to your maſk, couſin! I muſt brazen it out. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! you were not ſo happy in your diſguiſe, ſir. The pretty ſtagger in your gate, that happy diſpoſition of your hair, the genteel negligence of your whole perſon, and thoſe pretty flowers of modiſh gallantry made it impoſſible to miſtake you, my ſweet cuz. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Oh! I knew you too, but I fancied you had taken a particular liking to my perſon, and had a mind to ſink the relation under that little piece of black velvet! and, egad, you never find me behind hand in a frolic. But ſince it is otherwiſe, my merry-good-humoured couſin, I am as heartily glad to ſee you in town, as I ſhould be to meet any of my old •• ttle acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And on my ſide, I am as happy in meeting your worſhip, as I ſhould be in a rencounter with e'er a petticoat in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: And if you have any occaſion for a dangling gallant to Vauxhall, Ranelagh, or even the poor neglected Park, you are ſo unlike the reſt of your virtuous ſiſters of the petticoat, that I will venture myſelf with you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Take care what you promiſe; for who knows but this face you were pleas'd to ſay ſo many pretty things of, before you ſaw it, may raiſe ſo many rivals among your kept miſtreſſes, and reps of quality.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Hold! hold! a truce with your ſatire, ſweet cuz; or if ſcandal muſt be the topic of every virtuous woman's converſation— call for your tea-water—and let it be in its proper element. Come, your tea; your tea.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: With all my heart—who's there? Get tea upon condition that you ſtay till it comes.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: That is according as you behave, madam.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh! ſir, I am very ſenſible of the favour.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Nay! you may, I aſſure you; for there is but one woman of virtue beſides yourſelf, I would ſtay with ten minutes, (and I have not known her above theſe twelves hours.) The inſipidity, or the ra • cour of their diſcourſe, is inſufferable. 'Sdeath! I had rather take the air with my grandmother!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! the ladies are highly obliged to you, I vow.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I tell you what. The lady I ſpeak of was oblig'd to me, and the generous girl is ready to own it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And pray when was it you did Virtue this conſiderable ſervice?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: But this laſt night, the devil fetch me! a romantic whim of mine conveyed me into her chamber, where I found her young and beautiful, alone at midnight, dreſs'd like a ſoft Adonis, her lovely hair all looſe about her ſhoulders —

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: In boys' cloaths! (this is worth attending to.)

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Gad! I no more ſuſpected her being a woman, than I did your being my cater-couſin.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How did you diſcover it at laſt?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why, faith, ſhe very modeſtly dropt me a hint of it herſelf.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Herſelf! (if this ſhould be Jacintha.) Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ay, 'foregad, did ſhe! which I imagined a good ſign at midnight. Ha, couſin? ſo I e'en invented a long ſtory of a paſſion I had for her, (tho' I had never ſeen her before) you know my old way; and ſaid ſo many ſuch tender things—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: As you ſaid to me juſt now?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Pſh • h! quite in an another ſtyle, I aſſure you. It was midnight, and then I was in a right cue.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Well! and what did ſhe anſwer to all theſe proteſta • io • s?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why, inſtead of running into my arms at once, as I expected —.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: To be ſure.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: 'Gad! like a freehearted honeſt girl, ſhe frankly told me, ſhe lik'd another better than ſhe lik'd me; that I had ſomething in my face that ſhow'd I was a gentleman: and ſhe would e'en truſt herſelf with me, if I would give her my word, I would convey her to her ſpark.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Oh, brave! and how did you bear this?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why, curſe me, if I am ever angry with a woman for not having a paſſion for me; I only hate your ſex's vain pretence of having no paſſion at all. 'Gad! I loved the good-natur'd girl for it; took her at her word; ſtole her out of the window: and this morning made a very honeſt fellow happy in the poſſeſſion of her.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And her name is Jacintha.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Your amours are no ſecrets, ſir. You ſee you might as well have told me all, the whole of laſt night's adventure; for you find, I know.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: All! why, what do you know?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nay, nothing. I only know, that a gentleman's hat cannot be dropt in a lady's chamber.—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: The devil!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But a huſband is ſuch an odd, impertinent, aukward creature, that he will be ſtumbling over it.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Here has been fine work. [Aſide] But how, in the name of wonder ſhould you know all this?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: By being in the ſame houſe.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: In the ſame houſe?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ay, in the ſame houſe. A witneſs of the confuſion you have made.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Frankly's Clarinda, by all that's fortunate. It muſt be ſo. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And let me tell you, ſir, that even the dull, low-ſpirited diverſions you ridicule in us tame creatures, are preferable to the romantic exploits that only wine can raiſe you to.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Yes, couſin! but I'll be even with you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
If you reflect, couſin, you will find a gre ••
〈…〉 , in •• ocki • g a l •• y's m • de •• y, 〈…〉
her quiet, tainting her reputation, and ruining the peace of a whole family.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: To be ſure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Theſe 〈◊〉 your high-mettled pleaſures of you men of ſpirit, that the inſipidity of the virtuous can never arrive at. And can you in reality think your Burgundy, and your Bacchu • , your Venus, and your Loves an excuſe for all this? Fy, couſin, ſy.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: No, couſin.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What, dumb? I am glad you have modeſty enough left not to go about to excuſe yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
It is as you ſay. When we are ſober, and reflect but ever ſo little on the follies we commit, we are aſham'd and ſorry; and yet the very next minute, we run again into the ve •• ſa ••
〈◊〉
• dities.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What! mora ••• ing, 〈◊〉 ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: What you know is •• t half, n • t a hundredth part of the miſchief of my laſt night's f • olle. And yet, the very next petticoat I ſaw this morning, I muſt follow it, and be damn'd to me. Th • for ought I know, poor Frankly's 〈◊〉 may d • pend upon it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Whoſ •
• iſe, ſir?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: And here do I ſtand prating to you now.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Pray, good couſin, explain yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Good couſin! She has it. [Aſide.] Why, whilſt I was making off with the wench, Bellamy and he were quarreling about her: and tho' Jacintha and I made all the haſte we could, we did not get to them before —

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Before what? (I'm frighten'd out of my wits.)

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Not that Frankly car'd three half-pence for the girl.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But there was no miſchief done, I hope.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Pho! a ſlight ſcratch. Nothing at all, as the ſurgeon ſaid: tho' he was but a queer looking ſon of a bitch of a ſurgeon neither.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Good God! why, he ſhould have the b •• t that can be found in London.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ay, indeed, ſo he ſhould. That was what I was going for, when I ſaw you. [Sits down.] They are all at Jack Meggol's hard by, and you will keep me here.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I keep you here! for heaven's ſake begone.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Your 〈◊〉 is a damn'd while a coming.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You ſhall have no tea now, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Nay! one diſh.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No, poſitively, you ſhall not ſtay.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Your commands are abſolute, madam.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Then Frankly is true, and I am only to blame.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: [Returns.] But I beg ten thouſand pardons, couſin, that I ſhould forget to ſalute you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Pſhah! how can you trifle at ſuch a time as this?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: A trifle! wrong not your beauty.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Lord! how teizing you are? There.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: [Kiſſes her.] Poor thing! how uneaſy ſhe is! nay, no ceremony. You ſhall not ſtir a ſtep with me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I do not intend it. This is downright provoking. Who's there?

sp.speaker: Landla.
sp.p: Madam, did your ladyſhip call?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Does one Mr. Meggot live in this neighbourhood?

sp.speaker: Landla.
sp.p: Yes, madam, a fine gentleman, and keeps a noble houſe, and a world of company.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Very well. I don't want his hiſtory. I wonder my ſervants are not come yet.

sp.speaker: Landla.
sp.p: Lack-a-day, madam, they are all below.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Send up one then with a card to me. I muſt know the truth of this affair immediately.

div.head: SCENE I. A room in Mr. Strictland's houſe. Mr. and Mrs. Strictland diſcover'd; ſhe weeping and he writing at a table.

sp.speaker: Mrs. STRICTLAND.
sp.p: HEIGH! ho!

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: What can poſſibly be the occaſion of that ſigh, madam? You have yourſelf agreed to a maintenance, and a maintenance no dutcheſs need be aſham'd of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: But the extremities of provocation that drove me to that agreement—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Were the effect of your own follies. Why do you diſturb me? Writes on.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I would not willingly give you a moment's uneaſineſs. I but deſire a fair and equal hearing: and if I ſatisfy you not in every point, then abandon me, diſcard me to the world, and its malicious tongues.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: What was it you ſaid? — Damn this pen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I ſay Mr. Strictland, I would only—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: You would only!—you would only repeat what you have been ſaying this hour, I am innocent; and when I ſhowed you the letter I had taken from your maid, what was then your poor evaſion? but that it was to Clarinda, and you were innocent!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Heaven knows I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: But I know your Clarinda, your woman of honor is your blind, your cover, your—but why do I diſtract myſelf about a woman I have no longer any concerns with? Here, madam, is your fate. A letter to your brother in the country.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Sir—.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I have told him what a ſiſter he is to receive, and how bid her welcome.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Then my ruin is complete. My Brother!

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I muſt vindicate my own honor; elſe what will the world ſay?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: That brother was my only hope, my only ground of patience. In his retirement I hoped my name might have been ſafe, and ſlept, till by ſome happy means you might at length have known me innocent, and pitied me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Retirement! pretty ſoul! no, no! that face was never made for retirement. It is another ſort of retiring you are fitteſt for.—Ha! hark! what's that. [A knocking at the door.] Two gentle taps—and why but two? Was that the ſignal, madam? Stir not on your life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Give me reſolution, heaven, to bear this uſage, and keep it ſecret from the world. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I will have no ſigns, no items. No hem, to tell him I am here! Ha! another tap. The gentleman is in haſte I find. [Opens the door, and enters Teſter.] Teſter! why did not you come in, raſcal! [Beats him] all vexations meet to croſs me.

sp.speaker: Teſter.
sp.p: Lard, ſir! what do you ſtrike me for? My miſtreſs ordered me never to come in where ſhe was, without firſt knocking at the door.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Oh! cunning devil! Teſter is too honeſt to be truſted!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Unhappy man! will nothing undeceive him? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Teſter.
sp.p: Sir, here is a letter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: To my wife?

sp.speaker: Teſter.
sp.p: No ſir, to you. The ſervant waits below.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Art ſure it is a ſervant?

sp.speaker: Teſter.
sp.p: Sir! [ſtaring.] It is Mr. Buckle, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p:
I am mad. I know not what I ſay or do, or think. But let's read. Reads to himſelf.
Sir, we cannot bear to reflect that Mrs. Strictland may poſſibly be ruin'd in your eſteem, and in the voice of the world, only by the confuſion which our affair has made in your family, without offering all within our power to clear the miſunderſtanding between you. If you will give yourſelf the trouble but to ſtep to Mr. Meggot's, where all the parties will be; we doubt not but we can entirely ſatisfy your moſt flagrant ſuſpicions, to the honor of Mrs. Strictland, and the quiet of your lives.
Jacintha, John Bellamy.
Hey! here's the whole gang witneſſing for one another. They think I am an aſs, and will be led by the noſe, to believe every thing. Call me a chair. [Exit Teſter.] Yes I will go to this rendezvous of enemies —I will—and find out all her plots, her artifices, and contrivances. It will clear my conduct to her brother and all her friends.
Exit. Mr. Strictland.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Gone, ſo abruptly! what can that letter be about! no matter. There is no way left to make us eaſy but by my diſgrace, and I muſt learn to ſuffer. Time and innocence will teach me to bear it patiently.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p:
Mrs. Bellamy, madam (for my young lady is
married,) begs you will follow Mr. Strictland to Mr. Meggot's. She makes no doubt, but ſhe ſhall be able to make you and my maſter eaſy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: But how came ſhe to know any thing of the matter?

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: I have been with them, madam. I could not bear to ſee ſo good a lady ſo ill-treated.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I am indeed Lucetta, ill-treated. But I hope this day will be the laſt of it.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Madam Clarinda, and Mr. Frankly will be there: and the young gentleman, madam, who was with you in this room laſt night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Ha! if he is there there may be hopes; and it is worth the trying.

sp.speaker: Lucet.
sp.p: Dear lady—let me call a chair.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I go with you. I cannot be more wretched than I am. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. A room in Meggot's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Frankly, Ranger, Bellamy, Jacintha, and Meggot.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh, Ranger! this is news indeed. Your couſin, and a lady of ſuch fortune!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I have done the buſineſs for you. I tell you; ſhe's your own: ſhe loves you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Words are too faint to tell the joy I feel.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I have put that heart of hers into ſuch a flutter, that I'll lay a hundred guineas, with the aſſiſtance which this lady has promiſed me, I fix her yours directly.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Mr. Frankly, we have a deſign upon her which cannot fail. But you muſt obey orders.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Moſt willingly. But remember, dear lady I have more than life at ſtake.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Away then into the next room; for ſhe is this inſtant coming hither.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Hither? you ſurprize me more and more.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Here is a meſſage from her, by which ſhe deſires leave to wait on me this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Only for the chance of ſeeing you here, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
L ••
〈…〉 thee, tho' I know not how to believe it.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: P • pr'ythee, do not ſtifle me! it is a buſy day, a very buſy day.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Thou art the moſt unaccountable creature in life.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: But the moſt lucky one, Jack, if I ſucceed for Frankly, as I have for B • llamy; and my heart whiſpers me I ſhall. Come in, moſt noble Mr. Buckle; and what have you to propoſe?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: A lady, madam, in a chair, ſays her name is Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Deſire her to walk up.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p:
How could you let her wait?
Exit Buckle. You muſt excuſe him, madam. Buckle is a true batchelor's ſervant, and knows no manners.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Away, away, Mr. Frankly, and ſtay till I call you. A rap with my fan ſhall be the ſignal. [Exit Frankly.] We make very free with your houſe, Mr. Meggot.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Oh! You could not oblige me more!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Bellamy, pity my confuſion. I am to wiſh you joy, and aſk your pardon all in a breath. I know not what to ſay. I am quite aſhamed of my laſt night's behaviour.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Come, come, Clarinda, it is all well! all is over and forgot. Mr. Bellamy. Salutes.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I wiſh you joy, ſir, with all my heart, and ſhould have been very ſorry if any folly of mine had prevented it.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Madam, I am obliged to you!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: [Aſide.] I ſee nothing of Mr. Frankly! my heart miſgives me.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: And ſo: you came hither purely out of friendſhip, good-nature, and humility.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Purely.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: To confeſs your offences, to beg pardon, and to make reparation.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Purely. Is this any thing ſo extraordinary?

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: The moſt ſo of any thing in life, I think.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: A very whimſical buſineſs for ſo ſine a lady, and an errand you ſeldom went on before, I fancy, my dear couſin.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Never, I dare ſwear, if I may judge by the aukward concern ſhe ſhows in delivering it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Concern? lard! well! I proteſt, you are all exceeding pretty company! Being ſettled for life, Jacintha, gives an eaſe to the mind, that brightens converſation ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I am ſorry, with all my heart, you are not in the ſame condition; for as you are, my dear, you are horridly chagrine.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: But with a little of our help, madam, the lady may recover, and be very good company.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Hum! what does he mean, Mr. Bellamy?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Aſk him, madam.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Indeed I ſhall not give myſelf the trouble.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Then you know what he means.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Something impertinent, I ſuppoſe, not worth explaining.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: It is ſomething you won't let him explain I find.

div.stage: Enter a ſervant, and whiſpers Meggot.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Very well! deſire him to walk into the parlour. Madam, the gentleman is below.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Then every one to your poſts. You know your cues.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I warrant ye. Exeunt gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: All gone! I am glad of it, for I want to ſpeak to you.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: And I, my dear Clarinda, have ſomething which I do not know how to tell you. But it muſt be know ſooner or later.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Poor Mr. Frankly—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You fright me out of my ſenſes!

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Has no wounds, but what you can cure! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Pſhah! I am angry!

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Pſhah! you are pleas'd! and will be more ſo, when I tell you this man, whom fortune has thrown in your way, is, in rank and temper, the man in the world, who ſuits you beſt for a huſband.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Huſband! I ſay, huſband indeed! where will this end? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: His very ſoul is yours, and he only waits an opportunity of telling you ſo. He is in the next room. Shall I call him in?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: My dear girl, hold!

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: How fooliſh is this coyneſs now, Clarinda? if the men were here indeed, ſomething might be ſaid. —And ſo, Mr. Frankly!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How can you be ſo teazing?

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Nay, I am in downright earneſt; and to ſhow you how particular I have been in my enquiries, tho' I know you have a ſpirit above regarding the modiſh, paltry way of a Smithfield bargain—his fortune—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I don't care what his fortune is.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Don't ye ſo? then you are farther gone than I thought you were.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No, pſha! pr'ythee! I don't mean ſo neither.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: I don't care what you mean. But you won't like him • e worſe, I hope, for having a fortune ſuperior to our own. Now, ſhall I call him in?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Pho! dear girl—ſome other time.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p:
[raps with her fan.] That's the ſignal, and here he is. You ſhall not ſtir. I poſitively will leave you together.
Exit Jacintha.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I tremble all over.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pardon this freedom, madam,—but I hope our having ſo luckily met with a common friend in Mrs. Bellamy—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Makes any farther apology for my behaviour laſt night abſolutely unneceſſary.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: So far, Mr. Frankly, that I think the apology ſhould be rather on my ſide, for the impertinent buſtle I made about her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: This behaviour gives me hopes, madam. Pardon the conſtruction—but from the little buſtle you made about the lady, may I not hope, you was not quite indifferent about the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
Have a care of being too ſanguine in your hopes. Might not a love of power, or the ſatisfaction
of ſhowing that power, or the dear pleaſure of abuſing that power; might not theſe have been foundation enough for more than what I did?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Charming woman!—with moſt of your ſex, I grant, they might, but not with you. Whatever power your beauty gives, your good-nature will al • ow you no other uſe of it, than to oblige.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: This is the height of compliment, Mr. Frankly.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Not in my opinion, I aſſure you, madam; and I am now going to put it to the trial.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: [Aſide.] What is he going to ſay now?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: [Aſide.] What is it that ails me, that I cannot ſpeak? pſha! he here!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Interrupted! impertinent!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: There is no ſight ſo ridiculous as a pair of your true lovers. Here are you two now, bowing and cringing, and keeping a paſſion ſecret from one another, that is no ſecret to all the houſe beſide. And if you don't make the matter up immediately, it will be all over the town within theſe two hours.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Do you be quiet, can't ye! [Aſide.] But it is over, I ſuppoſe, couſin, and you have given him your conſent.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sir, the liberties you are pleas'd to take with me—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Oh! in your airs ſtill, are you? Why then Mr. Frankly, there is a certain letter of yours, ſir, to this lady.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A letter to me!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ay! to you, madam.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ha! what of that letter?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: It is only fallen into Mr. Strictland's hands, that is all; and he has read it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Read it!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Ay! read it to all his family at home, and to all the company below: and if ſome ſtop be not put to it, it will be read in all the-coffee-houſes in town.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A ſtop! this ſword ſhall put a ſtop to it, or I will periſh in the attempt.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: But will that ſword put a ſtop to the talk of the town—only make it talk the faſter, take my word for it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: This is all a trick.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Is it ſo? you ſhall ſoon ſee that my ſine couſin.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It is but too true, I fear. There is ſuch a letter which I gave Lucetta. Can you forgive me? Was I much to blame, when I could neither ſee nor hear of you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: [Tenderly]. You give yourſelf, Mr. Frankly, a thouſand more uneaſineſſes than you need about me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: If this uneaſineſs but convinces you how much I love you—interrupted again!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: [Aſide.] This is downright malice.

div.stage: Enter Ranger, followed by Jacintha, Mr. Strictland, Bellamy, and Meggot.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Enter, enter, gentlemen and lady.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Mr. Strictland here! what is all this?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Now you ſhall ſee whether this is a trick or no.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Do not be uneaſy, my dear; we will explain it to you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I cannot bear this trifling, Ranger, when my heart is on the rack.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Come this way then, and learn.

div.stage: Jacintha, Clarinda, Frankly, and Ranger retire.
Mr. Strictland, Bellamy, and Meggot advance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Why, I know not well what to ſay. This has a face. This letter may as well agree with Clarinda as with my wife, as you have told the ſtory; and Lucetta explain'd it ſo—but ſhe for a ſixpenny piece would have conſtru'd it the other way.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: But, ſir, if we produce this Mr. Frankly to you, and he owns himſelf the author of this letter.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: And if Clarinda likewiſe be brought before your face to encourage his addreſſes, there can be no farther room for doubt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: No! let that appear, and I ſhall—I think I ſhall be ſatisfied—but, yet it cannot be—

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Why not? Hear me, ſir. They talk.

div.stage: Jacintha, Clarinda, Frankly and Ranger advance.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p:
In ſhort, Clarinda, unleſs the affair is made
up directly; a ſeparation, with all the obloquy on her ſide, muſt be the conſequence.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Poor Mrs. Strictland, I pity her; but for him, he deſerves all he feels were it ten times what it is.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: It is for her ſake only that we beg of you both to bear with his impertinence.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: With all my heart. You will do what you pleaſe with me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Generous creature?

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Ha! here ſhe is, and with her the very man I ſaw deliver the letter to Lucetta—I do begin to fear I have made myſelf a fool—now for the proof— here is a letter, ſir, which has given me great diſturbance, and theſe gentlemen aſſure me it was writ by you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That letter, ſir, upon my honor, I left this morning with Lucetta, for this lady.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: For that lady! and Frankly, the name at the bottom is not feigned, but your real name.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Frankly is my name.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I ſee, I feel myſelf ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Now Mr. Strictland—I hope—

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: Ay! ay! a clear caſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied, and will go this inſtant to Mrs. Strictland.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why then the devil fetch me, if this would ſatisfy me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Nay, nothing. It is no affair of mine.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What do you mean, Ranger?

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Ay! what do you mean? I will know before I ſtir.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: With all my heart, ſir. Cannot you ſee that all this may be a concerted matter between them?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ranger, you know I can reſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Go on—I will defend you, let who will reſent it.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why then, ſir, I declare myſelf your friend; and were I as you—nothing but their immediate marriage ſhould convince me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Sir, you're right, and are my friend, indeed. Give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
Nay, were I to hear her ſay, I, Clarinda,
take thee Charles, I would not believe them 'till I ſaw them a-bed together. Now • eſent it as you will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Ay, ſir, as you will. But nothing leſs ſhall convince me; and ſo, my fine lady, if you are in earneſt—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sure, Mr. Strictland—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Nay, no flouncing! you cannot eſcape.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why, Frankly has't no ſoul?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I pity her confuſion.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Pity her confuſion!—the man's a fool—here, take her hand—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Thus on my knees then, let me raviſh with your hand, your heart.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Raviſh it you cannot; for it is with all my heart I give it you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And ſo am I, now it once is over.

sp.speaker: Rang
sp.p: And ſo am I, my dainty couſin—and I wiſh you joy of a man, your whole ſex would go to cuffs for, if they knew him but half ſo well as I do—ha! ſhe here! this is more than I bargained for. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: [Embracing Mrs Strictland.] Madam, reproach me not with my folly, and you ſhall never hear of it again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Reproach you! No! if ever you hear the leaſt reflection paſs my lips, forſake me in that inſtant. Or, what would yet be worſe, ſuſpect me again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: It is enough. I am aſhamed to talk to thee. This letter which I wrote your brother, thus I tear in pieces, and with it part forever with my jealouſy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: This is a joy indeed! as great as unexpected. Yet there is one thing wanting to make it laſting.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: What the devil is coming now? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Be aſſur'd, every other ſuſpicion of me was as unjuſt as your laſt; though perhaps you had more foundations for your fears.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: She won't tell ſure, for her own ſake. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: All muſt be cleared before my heart will be at eaſe.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: It looks plaguy like it, tho'! Aſide

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: What mean you? I am all attention.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: There was a man, as you ſuſpected, in my chamber laſt night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Ha! take care, I ſhall relapſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: That gentleman was—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Here is a devil for you! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: Let him explain the reſt.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: A frolic! a meer frolic! on my life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: A frolic! Ounds! They interpoſe.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Nay don't let us quarrel the very moment you declar'd yourſelf my friend. There was no harm done, I promiſe you. Nay, never frown. After I have told my ſtory: any ſatisfaction you are pleaſed to aſk, I ſhall be ready to give.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Be quick then and eaſe me of my pain.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why then, as I was ſtrolling about laſt night, —upon the look out, I muſt confeſs—Chance, and chance only, convey'd me to your houſe: where I eſpied a ladder of ropes moſt invitingly faſten'd to the window.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Which ladder I had faſtened for my eſcape.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Up mounted I, and up I ſhould have gone, if it had been into the garret. I opened one door, then another, and to my great ſurpriſe, the whole houſe was ſilent. At laſt, I ſtole into a room where this lady was undreſſing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and the devil! you did not dare ſure—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: I don't know whether I had dared, or no: if I had not heard the maid ſay ſomething of her maſter's being jealous. O! damn me, thought I, then the work is half done to my hands.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: Do you mind that Mr. Strictland?

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I do — I do moſt feelingly.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: The maid grew ſaucy, and moſt conveniently to my wiſhes, was turned out of the room; and if you had not the beſt wife in the world —

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: Ounds! ſir, but what right have you—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: What right ſir? if you will be jealous of your wife without a cauſe; if you will be out at that time of night, when you might have been ſo much better employed at home: we young fellows think we have a right—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: No joking, I beſeech you. You know not what I feel.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Then ſeriouſly, I was mad, or drunk enough, call it which you will, to be very rude to this lady; for which I aſk both her pardon and yours! I am an odd ſort of a fellow, perhaps: but I am above telling you or any man, a lye▪—damn me if I am not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I muſt, I cannot but believe you; and for the future, madam, you ſhall find here a heart ready to love and truſt you. No tears, I beg; I cannot bear them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Strict.
sp.p: I cannot ſpeak; and yet there is a favour, ſir.—

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: I underſtand you—and as a proof of the ſincerity with which I ſpeak, I beg it as a favour, of this lady, in particular [to Clarinda], and of all the company in general, to return to my houſe immediately; where every thing, Mr. Bellamy, ſhall be ſettled to your entire ſatisfaction—no thanks; I have not deſerved them.

sp.speaker: Jack Meg.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, ſir: the fiddles are ready; Mrs. Bellamy has promiſed me her hand; and I won't part with one of you till midnight; and if you are as well ſatisfied as you pretend to be, let our friend Rattle here begin the ball with Mrs. Strictland; for he ſeems to be the hero of the day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Strict.
sp.p: As you and the company pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Why this is honeſt. Continue but in this humour, and faith, ſir, you may truſt me to run about your houſe like a ſpaniel.— I cannot ſufficiently admire at the whimſicalneſs of my good fortune, in being ſo inſtrumental to this general happineſs.—Bellamy, Frankly, I wiſh you joy with all my heart! (tho' I had rather you ſhould be married than I, for all that.) Never did matrimony appear to me with a ſmile upon her face, till this inſtant.

lg.l: Sure joys for ever wait each happy pair,
When ſenſe the man, and virtue crowns the fair;
And kind compliance proves their mutual care.
